 LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 

 
Borrower 
 
Project Description 

 

  The People's Republic of China (PRC) 
 
  The Songhua River basin is the third largest river basin in 
the  PRC  after  those  of  the  Yangtze  and  Yellow  rivers.  It 
has  an  area  of  557,000  square  kilometers  (km2)  and  a 
population  of  62  million  people.  A  highly  productive 
agricultural  and  mineral-rich  region  despite  its  harsh 
winters,  it  is  also  highly  urbanized.  Cities  and  rural  areas 
alike on the sweeping floodplains are highly susceptible to 
major floods and face the risk of massive property damage 
and  loss  of  life.  The  Project  will  reduce  flood  damage 
through  integrated  river  basin  management  and  improved 
flood protection. Key features include a flood management 
system  to  modernize  flood  forecasting,  early  warning, 
land-use  planning  and  zoning;  and  flood  control  works  to 
increase  the  height  of  and  strengthen  existing  dikes, 
construct  new  ones,  and 
rehabilitate  and  upgrade 
reservoirs  for  wetland  management  and  water  storage. 
The Songliao Water Resources Commission (SWRC) and 
involved  agencies  will  also  be  strengthened  and  their 
project management capacity upgraded. 
 

 
  Environmental Protection 
Other: Economic Growth 
 

 
  Category B 
  An initial environmental examination (IEE) was undertaken 
for core subprojects, and a summary IEE was circulated to 
the Board on 17 August 2001. The IEE concludes that the 
environmental  impacts  are  primarily  positive  and  that 
negative  impacts  arising  from  construction  and  operation 
of project facilities can be mitigated to acceptable levels by 
implementing appropriate measures adopted in the project 
design. 
 

 
  Floods  have  produced  some  of  the  PRC’s  worst  natural 
disasters over thousands of years, and many flood control 
dikes  and  other  works  date  from  ancient  times.  Despite 
significant  construction  in  the  modern  era,  many  older 
works  fail  during  major  floods,  and  system  maintenance 
has been inadequate. Flood protection standards are only 
the  equivalent  of  about  a  20-year  flood  recurrence, 
whereas  the  Government’s  design  standard  for  important 
cities  is  to  protect  against  a  100-200  year  flood.  In  rural 
areas  the  design  standard  is  35-50  years.  The  PRC  has 
also  built  a  vast  network  of  dams  and  reservoirs  for 
irrigation,  water  supply,  and  flood  control.  Many  parts  of 
the  network  require  remedial  work 
their

The north and northeast of the country are important grain-
growing  areas  with  concentrations  of  heavy  industry  and 
agroprocessing  in  the  Songhua  River  basin.  One  of  the 
country’s major river systems, the Songhua River features 
major wetland areas of international significance. It is also 
where  major  cities  such  as  Harbin  and  Changchun,  and 
the PRC’s largest oil fields are located. The worst flood for 
over 200 years hit the region in 1998, threatening Harbin, 
severely  affecting  other  urban  and  rural  areas,  inflicting 
loss  of  life  and  damage  equivalent  to  $7.3  billion,  and 
significantly raising the poverty level. Modern nonstructural 
flood  control  measures,  including  flood  forecasting  and 
early  warning  systems,  are  urgently  needed  to  assist  in 
developing  an  integrated  approach  to  sustainable  flood 
management. Dikes need major repair and maintenance at 
vulnerable  points  along  the  Songhua,  Nen,  and  related 
rivers,  including  works  to  protect  the  cities.  The  dikes 
around flood detention basins and water storage reservoirs 
must  be  strengthened  to  reduce  the  risk  of  failure. 
Improved  management  of  wetland  areas  whose  natural 
function  is  to  absorb  floodwaters  and  maintain  wildlife  is 
also  needed.  Institutional  strengthening,  especially  of 
SWRC,  is  a  priority  for  a  basinwide  approach  to  water 
management. 
 

 
  The Project aims to reduce flood damage in the Songhua 
River  basin  through  integrated  river  basin  management 
and  improved  flood  protection.  The  Project  comprises  (i) 
implementing  a  flood  management  system  (incorporating 
flood  forecasting  and  early  warning  systems);  (ii)  flood 
control  works  comprising  upgrading  dikes  and  building 
new ones, and rehabilitating existing reservoirs to improve 
(iii) 
wetland  management  and  water  storage;  and 
supporting project management and institutional capacity. 
 

 
  The total cost of the Project is estimated at $357.7 million 
equivalent,  comprising  $134  million  of  foreign  exchange 
and $223.7 million equivalent of local currency costs. The 
Government has requested a loan of $150 million from the

 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  Report  and  Recommendation  on  a  proposed 
loan to the People's Republic of China (PRC) for the Songhua River Flood Management Sector 
Project. 
 

II. 

INTRODUCTION 

 
2. 
 The  Songhua  River  basin  is  the  third  largest  river  basin  in  the  PRC  after  those  of  the 
Yangtze and Yellow rivers. Located in the Autonomous Region of Inner Mongolia, and Jilin and 
Heilongjiang  provinces,  the  river  valley  has  large  cities  such  as  Harbin,  Changchun,  and 
Qiqihar;  automobile  and  chemical  manufacturing;  the  country’s  largest  oil  fields;  and  massive 
mineral  reserves.  This  productive  agricultural  region  is  susceptible  to  major  floods.  In  1932, 
20,000  people  drowned  in  Harbin  (nearly  10  percent  of  the  city’s  population  at  the  time).  In 
1998, loss of life was fortunately far less, but damage equivalent to $7.3 billion occurred.1 The 
poor and vulnerable suffer most from the floods. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided 
three  emergency  loans  for  rehabilitating  infrastructure  damaged  by  the  1998  flood.2 Following 
the  loss  of  life  and  property  in  1998,  the  Government  has  begun  strengthening  flood  planning 
and protection measures to prevent a recurrence of such loss. 
 
3. 
In  December  1999  ADB  approved  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  prepare  the  Songhua 
River  Flood,  Wetland,  and  Biodiversity  Management  Project.3 The  TA  assisted  the  Ministry  of 
Water  Resources  (MWR)  to  prepare  a  feasibility  study  for  an  integrated  flood  management 
project.  The  Appraisal  Mission  was  fielded  in  two  phases  during  21  October  to  3  December 
2001  to  finalize  the  objectives,  scope,  cost,  and  project  implementation  arrangements  for  the 
Project.4 A summary initial environmental examination (SIEE) was circulated to the Board on 17 
August  2001.  This  report  is  based  on  the  draft  final  report  of  the  TA,  Government  feasibility 
studies,  findings  of  ADB  missions,  the  SIEE,  and  discussions  with  Government  officials,  other 
aid agencies, and stakeholders. The project framework is in Appendix 1. 
 

III. 

BACKGROUND 

 
A. 
 

Sector Description 

1. 

Floods 

 
4. 
Vulnerability  to  droughts  and  floods  of  epic  scale  and  severity  has  made  the 
management  of  water  resources  a  central  preoccupation  of  the  leaders  of  the  country  for 
                                                 
1  The 1998 floods were the worst on record for the Songhua River and its tributaries. About 16 million people were 

directly affected, 154 lives were lost, and damage was estimated at $7.3 billion equivalent. 

2  Loans  1685/1686/1687-PRC:  Northeast  Flood  Damage  Rehabilitation  Project,  for  $330  million,  approved  on  22 
April  1999.  The  loans  covered  work  in  Heilongjiang  and  Jilin  provinces  and  the  Autonomous  Region  of  Inner 
Mongolia. 

3  TA 3376-PRC: Songhua River Flood, Wetland, and Biodiversity Management Project, for $1,545,000, approved on 
27  December  1999.  Supplementary  TA  financing  of  $250,000  was  approved  on  30  July  2001  to  provide  for 
changes in scope and cost overruns in the first phase. The project name was changed to the Songhua River Flood 
Management  Sector  Project  to  separate  interventions  aimed  at  biodiversity  conservation  from  the  Project,  and 
adoption  of  the  sector  lending  modality.  A  proposed  loan,  likely  to  be  cofinanced  by  the  Global  Environment 
Facility, for the Sanjiang Plain is included in the 2004 Country Assistance Program.  

4  The  Mission  comprised  B.  Carrad,  Senior  Project  Specialist  (Natural  Resources)/Mission  Leader,  AEFN;  Yang 
Junmei,  Programs  Officer,  PRCM;  D.  Tang,  Environment  Specialist,  ENVD;  L.  Blanchetti-Revelli,  Resettlement 
Specialist, AED; and V. You, Counsel, OGC. I. Fox, Senior Project Specialist (Portfolio Management), AWFN, was 
the  Mission  Leader  up  to  July  2001  and  also  assisted  during  the  Fact-Finding  Mission  for  the  period  14-21 
September 2001. 

 2

thousands of years. Records starting from 206 BC describe more than one thousand significant 
flood  disasters,  averaging  once  every  two  years.  Flood  management  in  the  PRC  has  been 
practiced  for  at  least  3,500  years,  and  many  flood  control  dikes  date  from  ancient  times. 
Originally  constructed  using  simple  techniques,  they  have  been  gradually  added  to  over  the 
centuries with the aim of securing greater security from flooding for a growing population. The 
older works are, in many cases, not capable of withstanding the increased hydraulic pressures, 
and  failures  are  therefore  common.  There  are  now  about  260,000  kilometers  (km)  of  flood 
control dikes nationwide. Such is the backlog of maintenance and strengthening work that the 
actual  standard  of  flood  protection  in  the  rural  areas  is  equivalent  to  a  flood  of  about  20-year 
average recurrence interval (ARI), while the general standard is 1 per 35-50 years. The current 
design standard for important cities is the 100-200 years ARI flood, while the actual situation in 
most cities is about 1 per 50 years up to a maximum of 1 per 100 years. 
 
5. 
Since  1949,  the  PRC  has  built  more  than  80,000  water  storage  reservoirs  to  try  to 
ensure  water  requirements  for  irrigation,  industry,  domestic  water  supply,  hydropower 
generation,  and  flood  control.  Despite  this  remarkable  engineering  achievement,  as  many  as 
400  of  the  PRC's  668  cities  suffer  water  shortages.  To  partially  address  the  problem  the 
massive  South-North  Water  Transfer  Project  to  supply  water  to  northern  cities  was  recently 
endorsed  by  the  Government.  Earlier  policies  support  large-scale  industrial  development  in 
remote, generally water-deficient parts of the country; thus, allowing factories unlimited access 
to state-financed water supplies contributed to the inappropriate use of scarce water resources. 
For the same value of industrial output, the PRC's factories use 5-10 times the amount of water 
used in developed countries.5 Similarly, irrigated agriculture has spread into some of the driest 
parts  of  the  country,  and  low  prices  for  water  provide  no  incentive  to  farmers  to  adopt  water-
efficient techniques. MWR estimates that as much as 60 percent of water diverted for irrigation 
is  lost  in  conveyance  through  leakage,  evaporation,  and  seepage  to  the  water  table. 
Spectacular floods have given the impression that the PRC has ample water, but the reality is 
that water availability in the country is only one quarter of the world average.6 
 
6. 
Floods  and  droughts  have  produced  some  of  the  worst  natural  disasters  in  the  PRC's 
history. In over two thirds of the country, annual rainfall is low (less than 600 millimeters [mm] on 
average)  and  drought  is  a  recurrent  specter. 7  Although  investments  in  flood  control  and 
protection  have  increased  steadily  over  the  last  two  decades  and  the  number  of  deaths  per 
flood  has  declined  markedly  due  to  better  flood  warning  and  evacuation,  the  cost  of  flood 
damage  has  steadily  increased. 8 The  reasons  for  this  are  complex.  Population  growth  and 
shortage of arable land have pushed many poor farmers to eke out a living in flood-prone areas. 
Improved flood protection (mostly dikes), and reclamation of wetlands and natural flood storage 
basins for agriculture and other purposes in formerly vulnerable areas have been supported by 
extensive  development  of  railroads,  highways,  and  better  communications  facilities  in  the 
floodplains. Deforestation and inappropriate agriculture practices have diminished water-holding 
                                                 
5  Li Peng. 2001. China Daily, 23 March 2001. 
6  World Bank. 2001. China - Agenda for Water Sector Strategy for North China. It covers the Huanghe/Yellow River, 
Hauihe,  and  Haihe  rivers,  where  people  have  only  5  percent  of  the  world  average  of  5,000  liters  of 
water/person/year. The Songhua River basin, not covered in the report, has slightly above the PRC average, or 4 
times the level of these three river basins. 

7  The  worst  drought  since  1978  gripped  the  nation  in  2001.  It  left  22.6  million  people  and  14.5  million  livestock 

without adequate drinking water, and devastated crops on 73 million hectares (ha) of farmland. 

8  The  risk  of  flood  damage  has  steadily  increased  despite  greater  protection  expenditures.  Risk  is  defined  as  the 
product of the probability of any given flood magnitude multiplied by the value of the infrastructure that would be 
damaged in that event. Increased standards of flood protection achieved through structural flood control measures 
are more than compensated by the growth of investment in flood-protected (formerly flood-prone) areas.  

 

 

  

3

capacity  and  simultaneously  promoted  more  rapid  rainfall  runoff,  causing  flash  flooding  and 
more severe soil erosion. The effects are cumulative, leading to increased flood heights and a 
perceived  need  to  continuously  strengthen  and  raise  the  flood  protection  works  to  ever-higher 
levels. 
 
7. 
The poorest members of society are most at risk from such calamities. In rural areas the 
poor often live in areas without adequate protection from floods or without access to irrigation. In 
urban  locations  the  poor  tend  to  live  in  low-lying  poorly  drained  areas  susceptible  to  flooding. 
The  direct  effects  of  floods  include  death,  injuries,  increased  health  hazards,  community 
displacement,  loss  of  property  and  productive  assets,  and  general  disruption  of  education, 
livelihood, and social life. The poor are ill-equipped to recover from such setbacks. Women are 
particularly burdened because tasks such as fetching drinking water, fuel, and food; taking care 
of children and elders; and feeding livestock__tasks traditionally falling on women__become more 
difficult during and after flooding. Winters are severe and floodwater can remain frozen in place 
and  give  rise  to  prolonged  saturation  of  cropland  and  loss  of  planting  stock,  destructive  frost 
heave 
floodborne  contamination  of 
groundwater. These impacts may persist for many months and inhibit the economic recovery of 
the poor.

low-cost  houses,  and 

2. 

Songhua River Basin 

 
8. 
Northeastern  PRC  comprising  Heilongjiang  and  Jilin  provinces  and  the  Inner  Mongolia 
Autonomous Region, is the PRC’s “gateway” to Russia and northeast Asia. ADB has begun to 
promote regional cooperation between Mongolia and the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region,9 
and other organizations10 are promoting regional cooperation in northeast Asia. Various cultural 
influences can be seen in the architecture of the main cities. A good transportation network of 
inland  waterways,  railways,  highways,  and  airlines  provides  access  to  Changchun,  Daqing, 
Harbin,  Jilin  City,  and  Qiqihar__the  key  centers  of  economic  development.  Changchun,  the 
capital of Jilin Province, hosts the automobile industry for the northeast region. Other industries 
include  chemicals,  food  processing,  and  a  host  of  secondary  and  tertiary  industries  and 
services. Harbin__the capital of Heilongjiang Province__and Daqing and Qiqihar have electricity 
generation, chemical, oil/gas, fiber, plastic, lumber, and textiles industries. Daqing is famous for 
its extensive oil fields, while Qiqihar has metallurgical, machine tool, chemical, gold mining, and 
lumber industries.11  
 
The Songhua River basin has a catchment area of 557,000 km2 (see Maps, pages vii-
9. 
viii) where about 62 million people live. The river originates from two main sources, the Nen and 
Second  Songhua  rivers,  which  meet  near  Songyuan  to  form  the  Songhua  River  (see  Maps, 
pages vii-viii). From this confluence, the Songhua River flows easterly to join the Heilong River 
on the boundary between Russia and the PRC. About 54 percent (300,000 km2) of the area is in 
the  Nen  River  catchment  area,  13  percent  (73,000  km2)  in  the  Second  Songhua  catchment 
area, and the remaining 33 percent (184,000 km2) is immediately adjacent to the Songhua River 
main channel. Average annual rainfall is low, varying from less than 400 mm in the west to more 
than 800 mm in the east. Most rain falls in June-September, and average rainfall in a wet year 
may be three times that in a dry year.

The river basin is demarcated by three mountain ranges: the Daxing’an range, which lies 
10. 
along  the  west  and  southwest  border  of  the  basin  in  Inner  Mongolia;  the  Xiaoxing’an  range, 
which limits the north and northeast part of the basin; and the Changbai range, which limits the 
south  and  southeast  part  of  the  basin.  The  forest  cover  in  these  ranges  provides  reasonable 
protection  for  the  water  resources  of  the  area  and  the  cascade  multipurpose  reservoirs 
developed  along  the  Second  Songhua  River.12 The  other  significant  landforms  are  the  Song-
Nen  and  Sanjiang  floodplains.  In  1999  and  2001,  the  Government  selected  Jilin  and 
Heilongjiang  provinces  to  become  two  of  the  country’s  three  experimental  “ecological 
provinces,”  acknowledging  their  rich  biodiversity  and  potential  for  sustainable  management  of 
natural resources.  
 
11. 
Harbin  (urban  population  2.6  million),  Changchun  (2  million),  Qiqihar  (1.1  million),  and 
Daqing (over 1 million) are all important cities located in the Song-Nen Plain, the larger of two 
major  floodplains.  A  network  of  flood  protection  structures  exists  around  cities,  key  rural  and 
urban areas, and flood detention basins. However, many structures are old and have not been 
adequately  maintained.  The  floodplain  is  a  productive  agricultural  area  for  grain  and  livestock 
industries,  having  been  significantly  altered  over  time  through  the  construction  of  flood 
protection  dikes.  Wetlands,  with  a  natural  function  of  absorbing  floodwaters  and  maintaining 
wildlife,  have  often  been  converted  to  commercial  uses,  which  has  increased  the  risk  of 
flooding.13 Over-drainage  and  mismanagement  of  the  available  water  resources  have  created 
sterile  areas  with  saline  and  alkaline  soils.  In  such  areas,  strong  prevailing  winds  cause 
extensive erosion in non-vegetated areas and the advance of sand dunes.  
 
The  second  major  floodplain  in  the  basin  is  the  100,000  km2  Sanjiang  Plain  (or  “Three 
12. 
Rivers Plain”) at the confluence of the Songhua, Heilong and Wusuli rivers. It is one of the most 
important  agriculture  production  areas  in  the  PRC.  Although  it  has  little  influence  over  flood 
levels  in  the  Songhua  River  Basin,  the  Sanjiang  Plain  has  the  largest  contiguous  wetlands  in 
eastern  Asia  (about  1.5  million  hectares  [ha]),  and  provides  globally  important  breeding  areas 
and  migratory  routes  for  waterfowl.  Large  parts  of  the  plain  have  been  drained  for  agricultural 
development,  and  the  remaining  wetlands  are  under  threat  of  further  development  for 
agriculture, industry, and construction of highways and urban facilities.14  
 
The urbanization rate is relatively high with 43 percent of the population living in cities or 
13. 
towns.  The  rural  population  totals  35.4  million  (57  percent)  and  about  17.4  million  ha  (31 
percent)  of  the  basin’s  area  is  farmland.  On  average,  each  rural  person  has  about  0.5  ha  of 
farmland__ranging from 0.3 ha per person in Jilin, to 0.8 ha per person in Inner Mongolia__higher 
than the national average. Only 22 percent of farmland is irrigated and much of the farmland is 
poor, especially in Inner Mongolia. Due to its susceptibility to drought and desertification, Inner 
Mongolia has the highest proportion of irrigated land (37 percent). According to one study by the 
Songliao Water Resources Commission (SWRC), 66 counties with a population of 32.7 million 
are at high risk of drought and flooding. In these counties, about 70 percent of the people live in 
rural areas. Average per capita income in rural areas is about Y2,200, half the urban average. 
Rural people and livelihoods are particularly vulnerable to floods and droughts.  
 
Thirty national- and provincial-level poverty counties are clustered along the banks of the 
14. 
Nen River and its tributaries, indicating a fundamental association between the concentration of 
poverty  and  flooding  in  the  river  basin.  The  incidence  of  rural  income  poverty  in  1999  was

better than in many other major river systems in the PRC.

Floods in the Songhua River Basin 

estimated  at  24.5  percent  overall,  based  on  a  per  capita  annual  income  of  Y1,300.15 Poverty 
was highest at about 31 percent in Inner Mongolia, 26.9 percent in Heilongjiang and lowest at 
about 20.3 percent in Jilin. The poor and the near poor (incomes below Y1,500) comprise about 
32  percent  of  the  total  population  and  are  highly  vulnerable  to  flood  damage  and  consequent 
losses and stresses. 
 
 
 
15.  Major  floods  occur  in  the  area  once  every  10  years  on  average.  Large  floods  in  the 
Songhua  River  basin  originate  from  rainfall  events  rather  than  snowmelt.  Large  rainfall  events 
can  be  generated  by  cold  fronts,  low  pressures  from  Mongolia,  Baikal  low  pressures  or 
typhoons.  As  the  basin  is  so  large  and  the  topography  varies  significantly,  storms  are  not 
distributed uniformly, and there are three geographic zones: (i) the Second Songhua, Lalin, and 
Mudan  rivers  and  the  tributaries  of  the  Songhua  River  entering  from  the  south;  typically 
typhoons or cyclonic storms bring large amounts of rainfall in a short period of time and these 
storm  events  are  usually  violent  and  cover  large  areas;  (ii)  the  Nen  River  and  its  tributaries, 
which  experience  less  intensive  rain  over  long  periods;  and  (iii)  the  southeast  side  of  the 
Greater  Xing’an  Mountain  Range  and  the  basin  of  the  north  bank  tributaries  of  the  Songhua 
River, which experience small and localized storms.  
 
Only  rudimentary  early  flood  warning  systems  exist  and  no  effective  coordination 
16. 
between  agencies  is  in  place.  Land-use  planning  and  controls  are  not  based  on  an  adequate 
assessment of a sustainable environmental balance. The responsible institutions, principally the 
water resources bureaus at the provincial/autonomous region level and SWRC overall, are not 
adequately  resourced.  During  project  preparation,  policy  dialogue  focused  on  the  need  for  a 
consistent legal/regulatory framework, improved transboundary coordination between agencies, 
and effective monitoring of river basin planning for comprehensive flood management. 
 
 
 
17. 
The worst flood recorded for over 200 years hit the Songhua River basin in June-August 
1998.  It  covered  137,000  km2 (25  percent  of  the  basin  area),  threatened  Harbin,  and  severely 
affected  other  urban  and  rural  areas.  The  Government  made  a  massive  effort  to  control  the 
floods and protect the people, countryside, cities, and infrastructure. During 45 days in July and 
August, 300,000 people laid over 12 million sandbags to reinforce dikes in the lower reaches of 
the Nen River. Despite this effort, the dikes breached in seven places. With the onset of winter, 
residual floodwaters were frozen in place for up to six months, especially across the flat Song-
Nen Plain. Official estimates show that 105 counties and 13.4 million people were affected, of 
whom  3.4  million  were  evacuated  from  their  homes.  More  than  0.9  million  houses  were 
destroyed  and  46  people  died.  Close  to  one  million  tons  of  grain  was  lost  and  over  619,000 
livestock  were  affected.  The  worst  affected  areas  included  28  poverty  counties  where  poverty 
increased significantly as a direct result of the 1998 floods. Rural and urban incomes, which had 
steadily  increased  throughout  the  1990s,  plunged  after  the  flood.  The  number  of  people  living 
below the Government’s poverty line increased from 3.5 million in 1998 to 5.2 million people in 
1999,  an  increase  of  52  percent.  Agricultural  losses  were  estimated  at  Y22  billion,  and  direct 
property  and  asset  losses  exceeded  Y36  billion,  for  a  total  economic  cost  of  Y52  billion  ($7.3 
billion).

Government Policies and Plans  

In reaction to the 1998 floods, the Government initiated improvements in flood protection 
18. 
for the major rivers Hai, Huai, Liao, Pearl, Songhua, Yangtze, and the Yellow River basin.16 The 
Government  recognizes  that  the  major  water  resources  problems  in  the  PRC  are  interrelated, 
and  that  their  resolution  requires  a  shift  from  a  sector  focus  to  a  more  integrated  and 
comprehensive  approach. 17  Specifically  for  the  Songhua  River  basin,  the  concept  of 
comprehensive  flood  management  is  expressed  in  the  ongoing  and  planned  activities  of 
provincial-level agencies, e.g., bureaus of forests, water resources, land resources, environment 
protection,  and  SWRC  for  wetland  conservation;  and  SWRC  and  Bureau  of  Water  Resources 
for soil and water conservation.18

framework  governing  water  resources 
legislative 
19. 
management. Laws deal with management of water resources at the national level and include 
the bases for integrated water resources planning and management covering water allocation, 
flood  control,  and  forest  and  wetland  protection  and  management.  Numerous  regulations  and 
organizations  implement  the  laws;  some  regulations,  however,  are  ambiguous,  inadequate,  or 
inconsistent.  Overlapping  or  conflicting  jurisdiction  among  agencies  leaves  important  issues 
unattended  and  inhibits  cooperation.  The  separation  of  institutional  responsibilities  at  the  river 
basin  and  provincial  levels  impedes  integrated  and  comprehensive  management  of  land, 
forests,  water,  wetlands,  and  ecological  functions.  Implementation  capacity  is  not  always 
effective due to centralized policies and laws, but decentralized financial responsibility and asset 
ownership.  Major  laws  affecting  river  basin  management  are  described  in  the  following 
paragraphs  but  certain  other  laws  are  also  relevant.19 Local  regulations  in  the  Songhua  River 
basin need further definition to achieve a consistent legal framework.

21. 
The  1997  Flood  Control  Law  was  the  first  law  for  the  prevention  and  control  of  natural 
disasters (replacing previous administrative regulations and other laws), and thus filled a gap in 
the  water  legislation.  It  addresses  the  specific  causes  and  remedial  measures  to  be  taken  to 
prevent  and  control  floods.  It  requires  a  unified  and  integrated  planning  approach  based  on 
comprehensive river basin plans prepared by the river basin commissions. The law introduced 
the designation of “planned reserve zones/areas” in which special rules may apply to land use 
and economic activities. It also provides for a flood impact assessment for any project in flood-
prone areas. MWR is primarily responsible for implementing this law. 
 
 
 

Institutional Framework 

3. 

a. 

Ministry of Water Resources 

 
22.  MWR  has  overall  responsibility  for  administrating,  planning,  and  managing  the  nation's 
water resources. Its mandate is based on the 1982 Constitution, which states that "all mineral 
resources, waters, forests, mountains, grasslands, unreclaimed land, beaches and other natural 
resources are owned by the State…." MWR's traditional role is planning and constructing major 
hydraulic  structures  and  multipurpose  projects  such  as  flood  protection,  irrigation  and  rural 
water supply development, and hydropower generation. In 1998, MWR gained responsibility for 
groundwater  administration,  but  its  mandates  for  hydropower  construction  and  biological  soil 
stabilization  were  removed.  MWR  retained  national  responsibility 
for  soil  and  water 
conservation. MWR is linked with and provides technical guidance to the provincial bureaus of 
water resources, which have comparable provincial-level responsibilities.  
 
23.  MWR  is  responsible  for  (i)  preparing  the  plans  covering  water  resources  in  national 
development,  (ii)  preparing  regional  plans  covering  more  than  one  province,  (iii)  planning 
associated  with  major  interprovincial  projects,  and  (iv)  formulating  comprehensive  plans  for 
designated interprovincial river basins for approval by the State Council through the river basin 
commissions and in cooperation with other departments and provincial governments. 
 
 
 
24. 
OSFCDR  is  responsible  for  flood  management  and  drought  relief  at  the  national  level. 
During  normal  periods,  OSFCDR  administratively  reports  to  and  receives  technical  guidance 
from  MWR.  OSFCDR  reports  directly  to  the  vice-premier  with  the  authority  to  direct  central 
agencies and provincial governors. The deputy secretary-general of the State Council and the 
ministers of Water Resources, Railways, Communications, and Civil Affairs are deputy chiefs.

administered  by  MWR.  Their  responsibilities  are  wide-ranging  and  reflect,  at  the  river  basin

External Assistance to the Sector 

ADB's Operations in the Water Sector 

the major flood of 1998, the Government increased the design standard for flood protection in 
the Songhua River and other major river basins. MWR also prepared a supplement to the 1994 
plan titled Some Suggestions for Improvement of Flood Control Construction of the Nen River 
and the Songhua River in the Short Term, approved by the Government on 5 April 2000. From 
1949 to 2000, the wetland area was reduced from 20,000 km2 to 6,500 km2 and soil losses and 
environmental  damage  increased.  Greater  attention  to  water  and  soil  conservation,  wetland 
protection, and maintenance of the ecological balance are given in the 1994 update. 
 
The 1994 plan and the 2000 supplement describe a comprehensive and integrated flood 
28. 
management plan for the Songhua River basin. Implementation was estimated to cost Y45.56 
billion  ($5.5  billion)  over  a  planning  period  of  15  years  (i.e.,  2000-2015)  and  covers  flood 
protection dikes, new reservoirs, rehabilitation of unsafe reservoirs, flood storage and retarding 
basins,  wetland  conservation,  removal  of  mainstream  flow  constrictions,  soil  and  water 
conservation,  and  nonstructural  measures.  The  provinces  and  autonomous  region  are 
committed to this plan. ADB will provide TA for preparing a 2004 loan project for the Sanjiang 
Plain, which is likely to include cofinancing from the Global Environment Facility (GEF).  
 
C. 
 
 
 
29. 
ADB’s  involvement  in  the  water  sector  has  been  significant,  especially  in  water  supply 
and  wastewater  treatment.  Since  1992  ADB  has  provided  15  loans  totaling  $1.97  billion  for 
water  supply,  wastewater  treatment,  and  flood  damage  rehabilitation.  ADB  has  also  financed 
TAs  totaling  $37.73  million  related  to  the  environment,  water  supply,  and  flood  control:  (i)  37 
advisory TAs on the preparation of policies and strategies, amounting to $23.98 million; and (ii) 
16 project preparatory TAs amounting to $13.75 million (Appendix 2). 
 
The  TA  for  strategic  options  for  the  water  sector  (footnote  20)  made  an  important 
30. 
contribution to strategic planning of water resources in the PRC. Several workshops were held, 
to  which  external  agencies  were  invited,  including  the  World  Bank,  Australian  Agency  for 
International  Development  (AusAID),  Canadian  International  Development  Agency  (CIDA), 
German Agency for Technical Cooperation (GTZ), and Japan International Cooperation Agency 
(JICA).  Key  issues  were  (i)  lack  of  unified  water  administration  and  management;  (ii)  gap 
between  policy,  planning,  and  implementation;  (iii)  inadequacy  of  financial  resources;  (iv) 
escalating  flood  damage;  (v)  water  scarcity  and  inefficient  water  use;  (vi)  increasing  water 
pollution;  and  (vii)  soil  erosion  and  ecosystem  degradation.  This  successful  and  influential  TA 
led to a much higher ADB profile in the water sector, including desertification.  
 
31. 
After the strategic options TA, a TA for national strategies for soil and water conservation 
helped MWR to address soil and water conservation comprehensively (overcoming the narrow 
demarcations  under  existing  institutional  arrangements)  and  map  out  a  strategic  approach  to 
control all forms of land degradation throughout the PRC.23 The final report on the TA was very 
well  received  by  the  Government  and  has  made  an  influential  contribution  to  developing  a 
comprehensive approach to addressing land degradation.

Lessons Learned

D. 
 
37. 
International experience suggests that floods can be most effectively addressed through 
an optimal combination of structural and nonstructural measures. The PRC tended to overstress 
structural approaches in the past, but it now increasingly recognizes the need to move toward a 
more  comprehensive  flood  management  approach.  The  devastating  1998  flood  highlighted 
nonstructural  measures  as  essential  elements  of  an  integrated  river  basin  management 
approach.  The  proposed  Project  will  serve  as  the  first  stage  of  a  long-term  commitment  to 
natural resources in the Songhua River basin. A 2002 TA will prepare a 2003 ADB loan project 
for the Sanjiang wetlands, East Asia’s largest contiguous wetland, in Heilongjiang (para. 28). 
 
38. 
The  importance  of  sound  watershed  management  was  pointed  out  by  a  number  of 
project  performance  audit  reports  (PPARs).  Many  communities  have  experienced  severe 
flooding  partly  due  to  the  effects  of  denuded  forested  uplands  and  watersheds.  Similarly,  the 
sector synthesis of postevaluation findings in the irrigation and rural development sector pointed 
out how lack of proper watershed management endangers human population and the physical 
environment.31 Postevaluation experience in the flood control sector in other countries resulted 
in recommendations to strengthen integrated river basin management. In designing river basin 
development  projects,  an  integrated  and  coordinated  approach  involving  upper  watershed 
management  and  conservation,  and  downstream  rural  development  must  be  simultaneously 
and  effectively  carried  out.  The  provinces  and  autonomous  region  have  ongoing  forestry/soil 
and water conservation programs to address these concerns. 
 
39. 
ADB’s  experience  with  rehabilitation  assistance  after  a  disaster  was  reviewed  in  1998 
and  provided  information  useful  to  flood  sector  projects.  Although  the  projects  reviewed  were 
generally rated as successful, achievements in terms of rapid restoration of facilities to ensure 
continuity of productive and social life were sometimes below expectations. Considerable delays 
occurred  due  to  (i)  delayed  loan  effectiveness,  (ii)  institutional  weaknesses  of  implementing 
agencies, (iii) slower-than-expected procurement of consulting services and other project inputs, 
(iv)  low  level  of  understanding  of  ADB’s  procedures  for  disbursing  funds,  and  (v)  unclear  or 
complicated subproject selection criteria and approval procedures. As a result, advance action 
in  recruiting  consultants  will  be  undertaken,  and  full  explanation  of  ADB  procedures  provided. 
Several  water  sector  projects  financed  by  the  World  Bank  in  the  PRC  have  been  delayed  for 
lack  of  counterpart  funds  during  implementation.  Letters  ensuring  that  adequate  counterpart 
funds  will  be  fully  provided  on  time  during  implementation  were  requested  as  part  of  loan 
appraisal. 
 
40. 
A recent World Bank study (footnote 6) indicated that existing institutional arrangements 
do  not  permit  a  coherent  integrated  approach  to  solving  water  problems.  River  basin 
commissions  operate  under  the  aegis  of  MWR  and  lack  authority  to  impose  river  basin 
management  over  other  ministries  and  provinces.  Current  water  allocation  arrangements  are 

                                                 
31 ADB. 1995. Sector Synthesis of Postevaluation Findings in Irrigation and Rural Development. 

  

12

based on periodic negotiations between riparian provinces and past climatic events, rather than 
on real time monitoring and river forecasting models. Project design has stressed the need for 
close  cooperation  between  all  parties,  and  several  workshops  were  conducted  to  foster  an 
appreciation of the basinwide approach. Specific loan covenants have been agreed upon (para. 
114).  Flood  management  measures,  a  basinwide  geographic  information  system  (GIS)  as  an 
input to mathematical modeling, a flood forecasting system, flood control command system as 
well  as  strengthening  SWRC’s  staffing,  training,  and  support  for  decentralized  planning  of 
nonstructural  activities,  are  included.  SWRC  will  play  the  role  of  overall  coordinator  of  flood 
management activities. 
 
41. 
Partly  due  to  fragmented  responsibilities  and  mandates,  but  also  as  a  result  of  the 
method of financing water-related institutes and activities, data on water resources in the PRC 
are  not  freely  available  to  potential  users.  Due  to  the  costs  of  the  survey  work  involved,  the 
collecting agency sees data collection as an investment and treats the results as capital. Other 
organizations or the public may only gain access by paying for it. Quite often large amounts of 
money  may  be  involved.  In  September  2001,  MWR  announced  through  MWR  document 
number 2001/377 that all hydrological data, i.e., real-time flood data and the basic hydrological 
data of hydrological stations at state level collected by MWR, are available to all users. MWR, 
SWRC,  and  the  provinces  and  region  have  agreed  that  water  data  in  the  project  area  will  be 
freely available from the start of project implementation. 
 
42. 
Implementation of the ongoing flood damage rehabilitation project (footnote 2) in the two 
provinces and autonomous region has proceeded well. It has shown that these instrumentalities 
have the capacity to implement a major project in the sector. ADB’s most recent review mission 
found physical progress to be ahead of schedule and 70-99 percent completion for all works in 
an  elapsed  loan  time  period  of  81  percent.  There  were  no  outstanding  issues  relating  to 
compliance  with  the  loan  covenants.  This  experience,  combined  with  the  hard  lessons  of  the 
1998 floods, has given the authorities the incentive to improve their cooperation in the future. A 
flood control headquarters has already been established in SWRC and provides the springboard 
for the Project to further strengthen institutional capacity.  
 
43. 
Under  the  Yellow  River  Flood  Management  Sector  Project,  an  associated  TA  on  a 
strategic planning study for the preparation of the Yellow River Law will assist in setting out the 
principles  and  procedures  for  integrated  river  basin  management  in  the  Yellow  River.  The 
Government places a high priority on devising policy, institutional, and operational innovations in 
larger river systems so that their lessons can benefit other river systems, such as the Songhua 
River.  
 
44. 
SWRC  and  the  other  agencies  are  aware  of  the  criteria  for  selecting  the  proposed 
subprojects, which are based primarily on the Yellow River project and were agreed upon with 
ADB.  There  is  little  apparent  risk  of  delayed  implementation,  since  the  provinces  and 
autonomous  region  have  experienced  working  with  ADB  and  have  smoothly  implemented  the 
ongoing  three  emergency  loans.  Although  SWRC  has  no  experience  with  foreign-funded 
projects,  it  has  the  backing  of  MWR,  including  additional  experienced  staff  who  have  been 
provided.  Project  assistance  will  be  needed  for  preparing  (i)  the  initial  environmental 
examination/environmental  impact  assessment  (IEE/EIA)  for  each  subproject;  (ii)  resettlement 
plans  (RPs)  for  subprojects  if  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  are  required;  and  (iii)  tender 
documents,  evaluation  reports,  and  disbursement  documents  necessary  for  ADB.  Training  will 
be given to SWRC’s project management office (PMO) and the PMO staff through on-the-job-
training in preparing these documents. International and domestic consultants who are familiar 
with ADB procedures will be recruited under the Project. 

  

13

ADB's Country Strategy 

E. 
 
45. 
ADB’s  strategic  objectives  for  the  PRC  are  to  (i)  improve  economic  efficiency,  (ii) 
promote  economic  growth  and  reduce  poverty  in  the  inland  provinces,  and  (iii)  enhance 
environmental  protection  and  natural  resources  management.  ADB’s  strategic  actions  in  the 
environment include (i) building institutional capacity; (ii) improving the policy, legal, regulatory, 
and  management  systems;  (iii)  promoting  cleaner  technologies;  (iv)  supporting  the  use  of 
economic  measures,  supply-side  measures,  and  other  measures  to  protect  and  ensure 
sustainable use of natural resources; and (v) promoting environmentally sustainable agricultural 
and natural resource management practice. The Project will address both ADB’s strategic and 
environmental objectives in the water sector. 
 
In  line  with  ADB’s  water  policy,  the  Project  is  promoting  an  integrated  water  resources 
46. 
management  approach.32 The  policy  emphasizes  that  water  is  a  socially  vital  economic  good 
that  needs  careful  management  to  sustain  equitable  economic  growth  and  reduce  poverty. 
Conserving  and  protecting  water  resources  through  a  participatory  approach  and  following 
principles of integrated water resources management are at the heart of the policy.33 
 
47. 
Sector capacities require strengthening. The policy environment, the sector institutions, 
and the human resources working in the sector all need upgrading. Relevant public and private 
organizations,  nongovernment  organizations,  and  community  organizations  need  help  with 
institutional  development,  water  policy  formulation,  legislation,  water  resource  planning,  real-
time  management  of  basin  operations,  data  management  and  interpretation,  simulation 
modeling  and  other  analytical  techniques,  socioeconomic  analysis,  community  skills,  and 
monitoring  and  evaluation  (M&E).  ADB  will  help  determine  priorities  and  selectively  assist 
through  a  process  of  monitoring,  training,  research,  and  feedback.  Good  practices  will  be 
interchanged  and  agencies  will  be  encouraged  to  adopt  systems  of  incentives  that  create  the 
demand from the public for improved capacity. 
 
F. 
 
48. 
An array of policy issues similar to those relating to the Yellow River project is relevant in 
the Songhua River basin. The following section draws on some of the material presented in the 
Yellow River Report and Recommendation of the President, but adds new material to reflect the 
differences  between  the  two  basins.  One  key  difference  is  the  provincial  ownership  of  the 
assets,  and  provincial  responsibility  for  financing  recurrent  costs  in  the  project  area.  In  the 
Yellow  River  project,  these  matters  are  basically  the  concern  of  the  central  Government  (i.e., 
MWR)  and  the  Yellow  River  Conservancy  Commission.  For  smaller  river  basin  commissions 
(e.g.,  for  the  Hai,  Huai,  and  Pearl  river  systems),  decentralized  ownership  and  financial 
responsibilities exist.

2. 

Legal and Regulatory Framework for Water Basin Management  

 
51. 
Environmental  management,  including  planning  for  conservation  of  natural  resources 
and protection of water resources, is a relatively recent concern in the PRC. Under the Project, 
the  current  flood  management  regulations  and  enforcement  provisions  in  the  basin  will  be 
strengthened.  This  work  will  advance  ADB’s  previous  assistance  to  strengthen  the  legal 
framework, e.g., ADB helped train the staff of the Environmental Protection Commission of NPC 
and assisted in drafting and revising some of the PRC's environmental laws.35 ADB is helping to 
promote an effective legal/regulatory framework for environmental protection that is responsive 
to  the  PRC's  transition  to  a  market  economy  and  adheres  to  international  environmental 
protection agreements (footnote 19). Further TA for legislative support for the water sector has 
been programmed for 2004.   
 
52. 
A  key  area  in  ADB's  policy  agenda  in  the  PRC  is  the  problem  of  transboundary 
pollution.36   ADB    is    helping    to    strengthen      institutions      and      address      transjurisdictional

Cost Recovery Mechanisms

Under  the  centrally  planned  system,  water  was  viewed  as  a  free  public  good.  Price 
53. 
signals  were  not  used  to  ration  a  scarce  resource  and  to  provide  incentives  to  conserve  and 
reuse  water.  Cost  recovery  techniques  were  not  used  to  generate  funds  for  investment, 
operation,  and  maintenance.  Thus,  pricing  and  cost  recovery  mechanisms  have  been  a 
constant theme of ADB’s policy dialogue in the water sector. The PRC’s policy to levy a fee for 
the  construction  and  maintenance  of  water  resources  infrastructure,  including  flood  control 
infrastructure, is set out in the Administrative Method for Collection and Utilization of the Water 
Resources Construction Fund (GF [1997] No. 7) and the subsequent Reply to Some Issues on 
Collection  of  Funds  for  Water  Conservancy  Construction  (CZ  [1998]  No.  135),  both  issued  by 
the  State  Council.  Instructions  for  their  implementation  have  been  issued.  Jilin  introduced  a 
Water  Resources  Construction  Fund  (1  January  1997  to  31  December  2010),  together  with  a 
Construction  Fund  for  Flood  Control  Infrastructure  effective  for  a  similar  period.  Heilongjiang 
established a Water Resources Construction Fund (1 January 1998 to 31 December 2010) and 
a Flood Control Infrastructure Fund (1 January 1999 to 31 December 2010). Inner Mongolia has 
introduced  a  Water  Resources  Construction  Fund,  but  is  still  to  issue  the  instructions  for 
establishing a flood control infrastructure fund. 
 
54. 
For  the  Water  Resources  Construction  Fund,  separate  funds  are  collected  at  the 
province, prefecture, city, and county levels. At the provincial level, the fund is financed by a 3 
percent  levy  on  vehicle  tolls  collected  by  the  Provincial  Highways  Administration  Bureau  and 
from the electric power construction fund collected by the Provincial Electric Power Bureau. At 
the prefecture, city, and county levels, the fund is financed by a similar 3 percent levy on vehicle 
toll charges together with levies on drivers’ training fees and municipal administration facilities. 
In addition, 15 percent is drawn from the municipal maintenance and construction tax collected 
by cities and counties with key flood control duties. The Water Resources Construction Fund is 
used with other funds for new water resources projects as well as repair and maintenance.  
 
55. 
The  Construction  Fund  for  Flood  Control  Infrastructure  is  similarly  collected  at  the 
province, prefecture, city, and county levels. It is financed through a levy on all institutions and 
individual business operators that have sole or business income in the previous year, on non-
agricultural land acquisition, and urban and rural people. For loss-incurring enterprises, the fee 
can be paid by contributions of labor or goods. The funds are collected by local tax, industrial 
and  commercial,  land  administration  departments  or  by  the  Provincial  Tax  Bureau  for 
enterprises directly under the central Government. The flood control fund must be used for its 
special purpose and the annual balance can be carried over to the following year. It can be used 
to construct dikes, reinforce reservoirs, supplement funds for key flood control works, and cover 
operational costs of flood control structures. 
 
56.

been the Nierji water resources project, absorbing about Y40 million; the remaining Y40 million 
has  been  spent  on  flood  structures  maintenance  and  construction.  In  Jilin,  Y70  million-Y80

IV. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
57. 
Floods  have  produced  some  of  the  PRC’s  worst  natural  disasters.  Despite  significant 
construction  in  modern  times,  many  older  works  fail  during  major  floods,  and  system 
maintenance  has  been  inadequate.  The  general  standard  of  flood  protection  is  only  the 
equivalent  of  about  a  20-year  flood  recurrence,  whereas  the  design  standard  is  to  protect 
against a 100-200 year flood for important cities and 35-50 years in rural areas. Many dams and 
reservoirs  for  irrigation,  water  supply,  and  flood  control  require  remedial  work  to  ensure  their 
continued  functioning  and  safety.  An  increasing  population  and  development  in  flood-prone 
areas have significantly increased the flood risk. The Government supports a shift in focus from 
flood  control  only  to  an  approach  that  emphasizes  flood  management  through  integrated  land 
and  water  resources  management,  optimal  water  management  throughout  river  basins,  flood 
protection  measures,  and  complementary  flood  forecasting  and  warning  systems.  Improving 
institutional capacity to adopt an integrated approach is a vital concern of the Government. 
 
58. 
The worst flood in over 200 years hit the Songhua River basin in 1998. It threatened the 
3 million people living in Harbin, severely affected other urban and rural areas, and caused loss 
of life and damage to property and infrastructure equivalent to $7.3 billion. The poor suffered the 
most  due  to  their  location  in  less  well  protected  areas  and  weaker  access  to  services.  Dikes 
need major repair and maintenance at vulnerable points along the Songhua, Nen, and related 
rivers, and works are needed to protect major cities such as Harbin, Changchun, and Jilin. The 
dikes  around  flood  detention  basins  need  strengthening  to  reduce  the  risk  of  failure,  and  the 
natural function of wetland areas to absorb floodwaters and maintain local ecosystems must be 
restored.  Nonstructural  measures,  including  flood  forecasting  and  early  warning  systems,  and 
improved  public  information  on  the  river  basin  itself,  are  needed  in  developing  an  integrated 
approach to sustainable flood management. Institutional strengthening, especially of SWRC, is 
a priority for a basinwide approach.  
 
59. 
The Government’s 10th Five-Year Plan and MWR’s Program for 2015 for the Songhua 
River  basin  provide  the  strategic  direction  for  implementing  flood  management  in  the  project 
area. The governments of Heilongjiang and Jilin and the Autonomous Region of Inner Mongolia 
are experienced in flood control and have the necessary capability to implement the proposed 
Project.38 Many relatively small-scale subprojects are dispersed throughout the basin and will be 
developed  in  stages.  ADB’s  sector  loan  modality  is  appropriate  for  a  project  that  comprises 
several core subprojects and about 23 subprojects to be identified and appraised in the course 
of implementation. A sector plan exists in the document Some Suggestions on Improvement of 
Flood Control Construction of the Nen River and Songhua River in the Short Term, which was 
approved by MWR and endorsed by the State Council after the 1998 flood. The Project qualifies

for this modality given that a sector plan exists, the institutions have adequate capacity (despite 
the  need  to  strengthen  SWRC  and  build  nonstructural  work  capacity),  and  there  is  scope  for

B. 
 
The  overall  goal  of  the  Project  is  to  improve  people’s  lives  and  to  promote  sustainable 
60. 
economic  growth  through  improved  river  basin  management  and  reduced  flood  risk  in  the 
Songhua  River  basin.  The  objective  is  to  reduce  flood  damage  in  the  Songhua  River  basin 
through  integrated  river  basin  management  and  improved  flood  protection.  Structural  flood 
control  measures  implemented  under  the  Project  will  enable  the  Songhua  River  to  convey 
floods up to the design standard, thereby ensuring that a flood equivalent to that of 1998 could 
be  conveyed  through  the  river  system.  A  flood  control  command  system  (incorporating  flood 
forecasting and warning systems) will be implemented to facilitate coordinated flood emergency 
response.  The  capability  of  SWRC  will  be  improved  through  training  and  capacity  building  to 
enable  it  to  assume  its  full  role  as  an  integrated  water  resources  planner  and  manager  of  the 
Songhua River basin. The details of the Project’s goal, objectives, and scope are in Appendix 1. 
 
 
 
61. 
Nonstructural  measures  are  essential  for  improved  flood  control  in  the  Songhua  River 
basin. The Project will strengthen the institutional capacity of SWRC to facilitate preparation and 
implementation  of  an  integrated  and  basinwide  approach  to  the  management  of  floods. 
Geographic information and flood forecasting sub-systems will be designed and implemented to 
build  a  fully  functional  and  basinwide  flood  control  command  and  decision  support  system, 
combining  telemetry,  teletransmission,  flood  forecasting,  and  early  warning  features.  The 
Project will provide all necessary hardware, software, and databases to cover all types of flood 
situations.  One  flood  control  command  center  will  be  managed  by  SWRC  and  another  will  be 
managed by each province and the autonomous region. Coordinating the system will be a key 
function of SWRC. Hydrological stations and workstations will be established in each province 
and the autonomous region. A public information center will be set up in SWRC and the existing 
web  site  will  be  upgraded  to  improve  communication  with  the  public.  SWRC’s  staffing  will  be 
strengthened  through  the  transfer  of  four  experienced  staff  from  MWR  and  the  provinces  and 
the autonomous region and through training offered under the Project. A mathematical hydraulic 
modeling  and  decision  support  system  will  be  prepared  from  which  maps  showing  the  likely 
impact  of  floods  of  various  magnitudes  (1:20  years  to  1:100  years)  and  plans/zoning  will  be 
derived  (Appendix  1).  The  focus  will  be  on  floodplain  areas  that  were  inundated  in  the  1998 
flood.39 
 
 
 
62. 
Structural flood control measures up to the national design standards will be undertaken 
to  enable  the  Songhua  River  to  convey  with  minimal  damage  floods  equivalent  to  that 
experienced in 1998. Flood control works will include (i) strengthening the existing flood control 
dikes,  and  in  some  cases  raising  the  dike  level;  (ii)  constructing  new  flood  control  dikes;  (iii) 
adopting  measures  (such  as  improved  slope  protection,  seepage  control,  and  foundation 
improvements)  to  increase  the  safety  of  flood  control  dikes;  (iv)  constructing  flow  control

watersheds in their ongoing soil conservation and reforestation programs.

Qunli dike is located at the new development zone in the western part of Harbin. 
It  will  protect  the  area  planned  for  the  city’s  expansion.  The  work  involves 
upgrading  an  existing  dike,  constructing  a  new  dike  and  several  temporary 
access  roads,  and  excavating  construction  material.  The  subproject  will  (a) 
reinforce  about  3.3  km  of  existing  dike,  (b)  construct  10.2  km  of  new  dike,  (c) 
provide riverbank protection (840 m), (d) plant a 30 m wide protection forest belt 
along  the  dike  works,  (e)  provide  10.75  km  of  slope  protection,  and  (f)  upgrade 
outlet structures. 

Xianghai reservoir supplies water for the Xianghai National Nature Reserve Area, 
a grade A nature reserve of international significance, which attracts tourists from 
abroad  and  domestically.  The  reservoir  protects  and  increases  wetland  storage 
capacity to supplement water for downstream reservoirs, and wetland areas and 
habitats  of  national  rare  wildlife  and  plants.  Several  safety  issues  need  to  be 
addressed: (a)  raise  the original design crest by 0.97 m, (b) reinforce or rebuild 
the upstream protection slopes of both the main dam (480 m) and auxiliary dikes 
(6.4  km),  (c)  demolish  and  rebuild  three  seriously  damaged  water  discharge 
sluices,  (d)  control  seepage,  (e)  expand  and  raise  the  selected  reservoir  banks 
and construct a new auxiliary dike, (f) build two access bridges, and (g) replace 
aging flood control telecommunication facilities. 

Du’erbenxin dike is 29.9 km long, and is along the Nen River’s mainstream at the 
confluence  of  the  Chao’er  and  Yalu  rivers.  Flood  disasters  not  only  cause 
property  losses  but  also  have  adverse  social  impacts  on  an  important  minority 
group.  There  are  three  main  components:  (a)  foundations  will  be  upgraded  and 
dikes  will  be  raised  and  widened  so  that  their  flood  standards  will  decrease  the 
frequency  of  flooding  from  1:20  years  to  1:35  years,  and  seepage  will  be 
controlled; (b) two utility crossings and three outlet structures will be constructed; 
and (c) all sections will be provided with slope protection and seepage control to 
guarantee their safety and stabilization.

68. 
The  Government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $150  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources  to  help  finance  the  Project.  The  loan  will  have  a  25-year  term,  including  a  grace 
period of 5 years, an interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s LIBOR-based lending 
facility, a commitment charge of 0.75 percent per annum, a front-end fee of 1.0 percent (the fee 
will be capitalized in the loan), and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft Loan 

  

20

and  Project  Agreements.  Local  currency  costs  will  be  financed  by  the  central  Government, 
provincial  and  local  governments,  and  ADB  ($223.7  million  equivalent).  The  Government  has 
provided ADB with (i) the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending 
facility  on  the  basis  of  these  terms  and  conditions,  and  (ii)  an  undertaking  that  these  choices 
were  its  own  independent  decision  and  not  made  in  reliance  on  any  communication  or  advice 
from  ADB.  The  financing  plan  is  summarized  in  Table  2;  details  are  in  Appendix  5.  ADB 
financing  is  41.9  percent  of  total  cost,  well  under  the  maximum  60  percent  allowed  by  ADB 
policy.  The  central  and  provincial  and  regional  governments  contribute  2.9  percent  and  2.5 
percent,  respectively,  and  local  governments/communities  contribute  52.7  percent  of  overall 
financing. The provinces and the autonomous region have given strong financial commitment to 
cover  provincial  PMO  and  recurrent  cost  responsibilities  in  each  area,  through  existing  and 
enhanced  cost  recovery  measures.40 However,  in  more  remote  and  poor  rural  locations,  the 
revenue base of local governments is highly constrained and these authorities face difficulty in 
financing  new  assets  (such  as  flood  protection  dikes  or  water  storage  reservoirs),  unlike  the 
major  cities  such  as  Harbin  or  Changchun  that  are  wealthier.  For  the  poor  rural  locations,  the 
Government  strongly  requested  local  cost  financing  of  $16  million  from  ADB.  Of  the  26 
subprojects,  17  qualify  for  local  cost  financing  support  from  the  ADB  loan  on  the  basis  of  the 
central Government’s assessment of weaknesses in the fiscal situation of the concerned local 
government  and  the  socioeconomic  assessments  (including  initial  social  assessments)  made 
during project preparation. Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, the poorest of the three areas, 
is the main beneficiary of local cost financing.

73. 
A  project  steering  committee  comprising  the  State  Development  Planning  Commission 
(SDPC), the Ministry of Finance, and MWR will coordinate the Project at the national level. The 
committee  will  monitor  progress,  coordinate  activities  involving  state  ministries  and  agencies, 
and  resolve  any  conflicts  or  potential  problems  or  cause  of  delay.  It  will  meet  at  least  once  a 
year. Following the disastrous 1998 flood, which initiated MWR policy documents such as Some 
Suggestions… and Directive on the Reform of River Basin Commissions, the vital role of good 
coordination of the various agencies and the provinces and autonomous region has become an 
important  priority. 42  As  a  result,  the  Songhua  River  flood  control  headquarter  (SFCH)  was 
approved  by  the  State  Flood  Control  and  Drought  Relief  Headquarter  (SFCDRH)  on  9 
November  2001  (SFCDRH  Document  no.  2001[10]).  SFCH  will  comprise  the  governor  of 
Heilongjiang  Province  (chairman),  the  vice  governors  of  Jilin  Province  and  Inner  Mongolia 
Autonomous  Region,  the  chairman  and  vice  chairman  of  SWRC,  the  directors  of  the 
provincial/regional  water  resources  bureaus,  the  directors  of  the  Northeast  Division  of  State 
Power Company, Heilongjiang Power Company, and Jilin Power Company. The office of SFCH 
will  be  in  SWRC. 43  In  addition,  SWRC  and  the  EAs  will  strengthen  intergovernmental 
coordination,  cooperation,  and  integrated  river  basin  management.  Responsibility  will  be 
assigned  for  areas  of  overlapping  or  conflicting  jurisdiction,  and  impediments  to  coordination 
between SWRC and the local governments will be identified. These may include the imposition 
of charges for the exchange of information (e.g., for hydrological and rainfall data).

In selecting structural subprojects other than for the three core subprojects, priority will

the  nature  and  scope  of  works;  (vi)  detailed  cost  estimates;  (vii)  an  economic  analysis 
demonstrating an EIRR of not less than 12 percent; (viii) procurement arrangements (including 
identification  of  any  international  competitive  bidding  requirements);  (ix)  implementation 
schedule; (x) financing plan; and (xi) arrangements for financial control and auditing.  
 
79. 
In  all  other  cases,  tendering,  contract  award,  or  other  implementation  activity  for  a 
subproject  may  take  place  with  ex  post  facto  approval  by  ADB,  based  on  a  feasibility  study 
(para.  78)  submitted  to  ADB  within  six  months  of  the  start  of  subproject  implementation.  ADB 
financing will, however, be subject to confirmation that any implementation activity undertaken 
was  done  in  accordance  with  ADB  guidelines  and  requirements.  Consultants  will  be  recruited 
under the Project to help the PMOs prepare the feasibility reports to the standard of detail and 
completeness required by ADB.

The Government is increasingly concerned with governance issues and has conducted 
well-publicized campaigns against official corruption. The Tendering and Bidding Law stipulates 
that tender and bidding activities will follow the principles of openness, fairness, impartiality, and 
good  faith  (Article  5).  This  law  covers  key  construction  projects  funded  by  the  State  and  all 
externally  funded  projects.  Article  6  stipulates  that  “no  organizations  or  persons  shall,  by  any 
means,  limit  or  exclude  legal  persons  or  other  organizations  outside  from  other  regions  or 
systems  from  participating  in  the  bidding  procedure.  No  illegal  interference  in  any  form  is 
permitted  in  the  bidding  process.”  Article  32  specifically  prohibits  bribes  and  collusion,  while 
Articles 49-64 specify appropriate sanctions for all abuses of the law, including substantial fines 
and  criminal  prosecution.  ADB  is  helping  to  develop  the  implementation  regulations  for  the 
Tendering and Bidding Law.46

primarily based on agriculture, including grazing. There are 16 national poverty counties and 14

103.  Central,  provincial,  and  local  governments  have  responded  to  the  pockets  of  poverty 
through a number of policy measures including development of interarea linkages, engineering 
flood  protection  mechanisms,  land  improvement  strategies,  improved  road  infrastructure,  and 
support  to  relieve  poverty.  However,  funding  shortfalls,  limited  development  of  stable  local 
income-earning  opportunities,  associated  technical  support,  and  credit  availability  continue  to 
hamper  poverty  reduction  in  these  areas.  Communities  of  national  minorities,  especially  of 
Korean and Mongol descent, are in the project areas and affected minorities will equally share 
benefits with national majority populations. The three core subprojects have no direct negative 
effects on minorities, and so no indigenous people’s development plan was required. However, 
in the event that a subproject with potentially negative impacts on a national minority is identified, 
action will be taken as required by ADB’s indigenous people’s policy. 
 

V. 

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION 

Economic Evaluation 

 
A. 
 
104.  The  Project  will  establish  the  capacity  to  manage  floods  in  the  basin  to  upgrade  the 
existing  flood  protection  system  that  shields  cities,  major  assets  and  industries,  and  supports 
the  sustained  livelihoods  of  about  62  million  people  living  in  the  floodplain  areas.  Each 
subproject  will  contribute  to  overall  flood  control  in  the  basin  as  well  as  protection  to  locally 
inundated areas. In particular, major economic assets to be protected are in the cities of Harbin, 
Changchun,  Jilin,  and  Qiqihar,  and  the  Daqin  oil  fields.  Although  their  role  in  the  future 
development  of  the  project  area  and  in  the  reduction  of  poverty  will  be  enhanced,  this  wider 
aspect  has  been  excluded  from  the  analysis.  The  analyses  were  limited  to  direct  and 
quantifiable benefits from local flood protection and, in the case of the core reservoir subproject, 
direct  benefits  from  flood  protection  and  incremental  economic  activities  attributable  to  the 
improved  reservoir  storage.  Economic  analyses  were  carried  out 
three  core 
subprojects__Du’erbenxin  dike,  Qunli  dike,  and  Xianghai  reservoir__to  evaluate  the  returns  on 
project investments to the economy (Appendix 11). The economic life of the project structures is 
40 years, including the construction period. A shadow exchange rate factor of 1.07 was applied 
to derive the economic cost and benefit streams. The economic wage rate of unskilled labor is 
90  percent  of  the  financial  wage  rates.  Estimated  benefits  from  the  subprojects  were  derived 
based  on  avoidance  of  damage  to  existing  assets,  avoided  disruptions  to  agricultural  and 
industrial production, and avoided emergency repairs of the dikes. Key assets in the flood-prone 
areas  include  standing  crops,  public  infrastructure,  and  buildings  (residential,  commercial,  and 
industrial).  The  economic  benefits  for  the  Xianghai  reservoir  subproject  reflect  the  benefits  of 
flood  protection,  gains  to  wildlife  protection  that  result  from  increased  tourism  activity  in  the 
subproject  area,  and  the  benefits  from  increased  water  storage,  which  will  reduce  the  risk  of 
flooding  and  increase  production.  The  subproject  will  also  yield  substantial  environmental 
benefits  from  an  improved  wetland  area  and  limited  flood  protection  for  the  overall  floodplain, 
but these benefits were not quantified. 
 
105.  To calculate the EIRRs, core subproject benefits were annualized by adjusting the total 
estimated  flood  damages  by  the  probabilities  of  floods,  under  the  with-project  and  without-

the 

for 

  

30

project scenarios. The magnitude of damage in the subproject areas was adjusted according to 
the expected levels of inundation as indicated by the involved design institutes.49 For the rural 
flood-prone areas, benefits were derived mostly from the lower risk of damage predominantly to 
agricultural  crops.  However,  their  potential  for  growth  given  adequate  protection  was  fully 
recognized. In areas with good potential for economic growth__such as Harbin City, which will be 
protected  by  the  Qunli  dike__benefits  were  derived  from  enhanced  industrial  and  agricultural 
growth made possible by investment in the core subproject.  
 
106.  The  costs  of  subprojects  include  the  costs  of  land  acquired,  resettlement,  survey  and 
designs,  construction,  construction  supervision,  environment  mitigation  measures,  and 
subproject  management.  The  costs  of  land  acquisition  and  temporary  construction  sites  are 
based  on  the  local  compensation  standards.  For  example,  the  cost  for  the  Qunli  dike  is 
estimated at about Y14.7 million for 114 ha and 60 households to be resettled permanently, and 
Y556,000  for  the  269  ha  of  grassland  required  as  borrow  areas.  Compensation  costs  for 
structures dismantled as part of resettlement activities were based on their reconstruction costs.  
 
107.  The  estimated  EIRRs  for  the  core  subprojects  are  13.4  for  Du’erbenxin  dike,  26.7  for 
Qunli  dike,  and  13.6  percent  for  Xianghai  reservoir.  The  wide  range  between  the  Du’erbenxin 
dike and Qunli dike subprojects reflects the diversity of benefits that should be anticipated from 
investing  in  flood  protection  in  rural  areas  compared  with  investment  in  the  urban  fringe  of  a 
large city. The EIRR for the Xianghai reservoir subproject reflects the gains to wildlife protection, 
which  will  result  in  increased  tourism  activity  in  the  subproject  area;  increased  water  storage, 
which  will  result  in  reduced  risk  and  increased  reed  production  in  the  wetlands;  increased 
fisheries  in  the  reservoir;  and  increased  agricultural  production  downstream  of  the  wetlands. 
Similar  EIRRs  are  expected  for  the  other  candidate  subprojects  in  the  Project.  The  estimates 
are robust, given the relatively limited scope of benefits quantified in the economic evaluation. 
The  benefit  estimates  excluded  the  avoidance  of  injuries,  hospitalization,  and  loss  of  lives; 
mobilization  of  flood-fighting  crews;  and  large-scale  emergency  evacuation  that  occur  during 
major floods. The economic evaluation excluded potential loss, such as loss due to disruption of 
communication  and  transportation  to  areas  adjacent  to  flood-prone  zones;  and  loss  of 
household assets, livestock, and farm machinery.  
 
B. 
 
108.  As  demonstrated  by  the  1998  flood,  inundation  created  widespread  hardship  for 
floodplain  residents  regardless  of  their  income  status;  however,  the  poor  were  hurt  the  most. 
Aside  from  direct  tangible  financial  losses,  the  direct  effects  of  floods  include  death,  injuries, 
health  hazards,  community  displacement,  loss  of  property  and  productive  assets,  and  general 
disruption  to  education,  livelihood,  and  social  life.  Relocation  of  flood  victims  to  congested 
evacuation  camps  creates  fertile  conditions  for  disease  and  social  tension,  while  the  need  to 
reconstruct  houses  and  buildings  puts  additional  burdens  on  local  communities.  Women,  who 
form a substantial percentage of the labor force, are particularly burdened by flooding as some 
of  the  activities  they  carry  out,  such  as  fetching  drinking  water,  fuel,  and  food;  taking  care  of 
children  and  elders;  and  feeding  livestock  become  extremely  difficult  during  heavy  flooding. 
Flood-affected  families  contribute  labor  to  relief  and  emergency  works  and  participate  in  the 
cleanup and recovery efforts after floodwaters have receded. Finally, flooding causes subtler yet 
longer  term  losses  to  farm  communities  as  waterlogging  greatly  reduces  the  productivity  of 
agricultural land. Recent floods have threatened main urban areas. A major flood in a large city 
remains a possibility, with the existing flood protection infrastructure.  

Social Dimensions 

                                                 
49 The design institutes for Jilin Province, Heilongjiang Province, and the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. 

  

31

Impact on Poverty 

C. 
 
109.  The  extent  of  poverty  in  the  Songhua  River  basin  (para.  14),  as  well  as  the  income 
effects  of  the  1998  floods  (paras.  17-18)  have  been  noted.50 About  10.2  million  people,  or  16 
percent of the population, live in 30 poverty counties in the project area. About 70 percent of the 
population  of  these  poverty  counties  live  in  rural  areas  and  the  average  per  capita  income  is 
Y1,700__22 percent less than the average in the project area.  
 
110.  Two    core    subproject    areas__Du’erbenxin    in    Zalaite    Banner,  Inner    Mongolia,51 and 
Xianghai in Tongyu County, Jilin__are located in poor rural areas. The third, Qunli, is located in 
Daoli  District,  Heilongjiang,  in  the  vicinity  of  Harbin  City,  a  less-poor  urban  area.  Average  per 
capita net annual incomes for Zalaite Banner and Tongyu County are about Y1,200 and Y1,040, 
respectively.52 Average  annual  incomes  in  the  three  villages  comprising  the  Qunli  subproject 
area  are  substantially  higher  at  Y4,196,  reflecting  the  urban  nature  of  this  area.  Poverty 
incidence in the rural subproject areas is about 80 percent for Du’erbenxin and 75 percent for 
Xianghai,  but  only  about  17  percent  in  the  urban  area  of  Qunli.53 Rural  poverty  is  caused  by 
location, limited resource base and land quality, lack of skills and income-earning opportunities 
from nonagriculture livelihoods, and poor health status of adults; and is positively correlated with 
the  occurrence  of  ethnic  minorities.  In  addition  to  high  poverty,  the  two  rural  subproject  areas 
have  a  significant  ethnic  minority  population:  34  percent  in  Xianghai  and  58  percent  in 
Du’erbenxin. Both are minority townships (Appendix 12). 
 
111.  The  Project  will  support  the  poverty  reduction  trends  over  the  decades  in  the  project 
areas  that  were  abruptly  reversed  by  the  effects  of  the  1998  floods.  The  Project  will  provide 
approximately 5.3 million person-days of manual employment, generating employment for about 
45,000 unskilled laborers over the next four years. About 1.1 million person-days required at the 
three  core  subproject  sites  will  mean  20-150  days  of  employment  for  each  of  8,600  unskilled 
laborers.  Based  on  the  estimated  poverty  incidence  at  the  subproject  sites  and  with  priority 
given  to  the  poor,  about  half  of  the  employment  estimated  to  be  worth  about  Y460  million  in 
wages  will  be  directed  to  poor  households.  Jobs  for  maintaining  the  new  and  rehabilitated 
infrastructure, the cost of which is estimated at 1 percent of the construction cost or about Y8 
million per year, are likely to provide about 10,000 person-days employment per year. Incomes 
earned from construction work will give households the opportunity to build savings and reduce 
the  risk  of  falling  back  into  poverty.  The  three  core  subprojects  were  analyzed  to  assess  the 
distribution  of  benefits  to  project  stakeholders:  the  households,  industry,  and  the  public 
sector/economy. The extent to which the Project directly benefits the poor was also determined. 
The poverty impact ratios are 0.80 for the Du’erbenxin dike, 0.18 for the Qunli dike, and 0.94 for 
the Xianghai reservoir (Appendix 12). 
 
D. 
 
112.  The project design takes into account potential technical and economic risks. The main 
risks__which  could  result  in  implementation  delays  and  cost  overruns__are  associated  with 
abnormal rainfall and unexpected floods. They can be compounded by the long winter season 
and  could  adversely  affect  the  construction  of  dikes  and  river  training  works  during  project
