implementation.  To  mitigate  these  risks,  the  design  includes  measures  to  facilitate  rapid 
implementation  and  avoids  construction  during  the  rainy  season.  Advance  action  for 
procurement and consultant recruitment, and retroactive financing are expected to substantially 
shorten  the  time  before  construction  starts.  Adequate  amounts  of  the  loan  proceeds  will  be 
made  available  on  time  through  imprest  accounts.  The  provision  of  project  management 
consultants will also expedite subproject selection and preparation of IEE/EIA and RPs. These 
measures should mitigate the risk of delayed implementation. 
 
113.  Other  risks  outlined  in  Appendix  1  are  the  need  for  a  high  level  of  commitment  to  the 
river  basin  approach  to  flood  management,  acceptance  by  the  provinces  and  autonomous 
region  of  zoning  regulations,  and  additional  cost  recovery  measures.  Ongoing  policy  dialogue 
during  implementation,  the  impact  of  the  planned  study  tours  and  training,  and  increased 
awareness generally in the PRC of the need for a holistic approach are anticipated to overcome 
the risks. Local cost financing from ADB has been introduced in remote and poor rural locations 
to mitigate the risk of shortages of counterpart funds.

Appendix 4, page 1 

DESCRIPTION OF CORE SUBPROJECTS 

Qunli Embankment 

Three core subprojects to be undertaken will reflect the variety of the problems, location, 

 
1. 
Structural flood control measures will enable the Songhua River to convey floods up to 
the  relevant  national  design  standards  and  will  ensure  that  a  flood  equivalent  to  that  of  1998 
could  be  conveyed  through  the  river  system  with  minimum  damage.  Flood  control  works  will 
include  (i)  strengthening  the  existing  flood  embankments;  (ii)  constructing  new  flood  control 
embankments;  (iii)  adopting  measures  to  increase  the  safety  of  flood  control  embankments 
(such as improved slope protection, seepage control measures, and foundation improvements); 
and  (iv)  providing  flow  control  structures  and  associated  works  to  increase  the  flood  storage 
capacity  of  flood  detention  basins  such  as  that  at  Xianghai  reservoir,  which  supports  an 
important wetland conservation reserve. Such measures will be implemented adjacent to major 
urban  areas,  including  the  cities  of  Harbin,  Changchun,  Jilin,  and  Ulanhot;  at  important  rural 
sites; and in key areas containing major strategic assets such as the Daqing oil fields, China’s 
largest oil-producing area. 
 
2. 
scale of works, accessibility, and urgency. They are as follows. 
 
A. 
 
The  Qunli  embankment  is  at  the  new  development  zone  in  the  western  part  of  Harbin, 
3. 
the largest city along the Songhua River and capital of Heilongjiang Province. Many floods have 
been recorded in Harbin during the historical period of flood records, the most recent one being 
in 1998. The flood risk in Harbin and its surroundings has increased gradually over the past 10-
20  years  mainly  due  to  a  substantial  increase  of  fixed  assets,  and  also  to  serious  floods  with 
apparent  higher  frequency  and  magnitude.  The  Project  aims  at  a  comprehensive  plan  for  an 
increased  flood  protection  standard,  for  both  city  and  suburbs.  The  core  subproject  aims  at 
upgrading  and  constructing  dikes  for  town  protection  and  expansion.  The  Qunli  area,  being 
about  24  square  kilometers  (km2),  and  at  present  comprising  several  small  villages  with  a 
population  of  about  5,400  and  a  protection  standard  of  20  years,  will  become  the  site  for  the 
planned  growth  of  the  city  with  public  facilities,  transport  and  other  infrastructure,  commercial 
area, services, schools, and residential area. The population will reach approximately 365,500 
and the flood protection standard has to be raised to 50 years. The work involves upgrading an 
existing  embankment,  constructing  a  new  embankment  and  several  temporary  access  roads, 
and  excavating  construction  material.  The  subproject  aims  to  (i)  reinforce  about  3.3  km  of 
existing  embankment;  (ii)  construct  10.2  km  of  new  embankment  and  840  m  of  riverbank 
protection;  (iv)  plant  a  30-meter-wide  protection  forest  belt  along  the  embankment  works;  and 
(iv) establish 10.75 km of slope protection, as well as upgrade outlet structures. 
 
B. 
 
Xianghai  reservoir  is  located  near  Xianghai  town,  Baicheng  Administration  Area,  in 
4. 
Tongyu  county  in  the  west  of  Jilin  Province,  near  the  provincial  border  with  the  Autonomous 
Region of Inner Mongolia. The reservoir was constructed in 1971-1973 and consists of two parts 
with a total design surface area of 71 km2 and a volume of 228 million cubic meters (m3). The 
main  water  sources  of  the  reservoir  are  the  Longhuatu  diversion  of  the  Taoer  River  and 
Huolin/Ermutai  River.  Construction  of  the  reservoir  served  two  objectives:  flood  control,  and 
water  supply  for  the  Xianghai  National  Nature  Reserve  Area,  a  grade  A  nature  reserve  of 
international  significance.  The  reservoir  increases  the  wetland  storage  capacity  to  supplement 
water  for  downstream  reservoirs,  and  protects  the  wetland  area  and  habitat  of  national  rare 
wildlife  and  plants.  The  reservoir  has  several  safety  issues  that  need  to  be  addressed:  low 

Xianghai Reservoir 

 45 

Appendix 4, page 2 

construction and maintenance standards that lead to severe leakage problems. As a result, the 
present surface area is only 48 km2. The major issues are as follows. 

 

(i) 

The original design crest elevation is insufficient to reach the original design value 
(surface area and volume), upstream protection slopes of both main dam (480 m) 
and auxiliary embankments (6.4 km) are heavily damaged. 

(ii)  Three water discharge sluices are seriously damaged. 
(iii)  Seepage causes severe water losses. 
(iv)  The elevation of several banks is insufficient, and a new auxiliary embankment is 

(v)  Communication  problems  due  to  lack  of  access  bridges  between  the  two  lakes 

needed. 

hamper reservoir operation. 

(vi)  Flood control telecommunication facilities are old and inefficient. 

Du’erbenxin Embankment 

 
5. 
The  project  aims  to  increase  and  restore  the  original  crest  elevation  of  the  main  dam 
and  auxiliary  embankments,  reconstruct  and  reinforce  slope  protection,  control  seepage, 
reconstruct  three  sluicing  structures,  construct  two  access  bridges,  and  install  flood  control 
telecommunication facilities. 
 
C. 
 
6. 
Du’erbenxin  is  a  township  in  the  Northeast  Zalaite  Banner  of  Xing’an  League  of  the 
Autonomous Region of Inner Mongolia. It is on an alluvial plain at the confluence of the Chao’er 
and Yalu rivers with the Nen River. Du’erbenxin plain is surrounded by water on three sides and 
the plain declines gradually from northwest to southeast. The highest point is Manghai Mountain 
in the south of Du’erbenxin at 153.6 meters above sea level. The Du’erbenxin embankment is 
29.9  km  long  along  the  Nen  River’s  main  stream,  at  the  confluence  of  the  Chao’er  and  Yalu 
rivers.    Flood  disasters  have  not  only  caused  substantial  property  losses  but  also  produced 
severe social impacts on an important minority group. The backwater effect from Nen River and 
the resulting long duration of stagnant water conditions on Du’erbenxin plain cause large crop 
losses. The present dikes were constructed by the local people with a flood protection standard 
of  10  years,  but  now  suffer  from  seepage  and  leakage  problems,  as  well  as  damage  to  the 
embankment  slopes.  The  subproject  will  protect  residents  and  farmlands  on  the  two  banks 
through these three main components include. 
 

(i) 

Foundations will be upgraded and embankments will be raised and widened up to 
a  higher  flood  standard,  i.e.,  the  frequency  of  flooding  will  decrease  from  once 
every 20 years to once every 35 years, and seepage will be controlled. 

(ii)  Two  utility  crossings  and  two  outlet  structures  will  be  constructed;  one  outlet 

(iii)  All  sections  will  be  provided  with  slope  protection  and  seepage  control  to 

structure will be rehabilitated.  

guarantee their safety and stabilization.

Appendix 5, page 1 

COST ESTIMATES 

Introduction 

 
1. 
 
The  total  project  cost  is  estimated  at  Y2,958  million  ($357.7  million),  of  which  Y1,109 
1. 
million  ($134  million)  is  the  foreign  exchange  cost.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will 
finance  $150  million  of  the  project  cost,  comprising  the  total  foreign  exchange  cost  and  $16 
million  equivalent  of  the  local  currency  cost,  or  41.9  percent  of  the  project  cost.  The  ADB 
financing will cover interest during construction (IDC), commitment charges, and front-end fee. 
The  total  project  cost,  excluding  IDC  and  commitment  and  front-end  fees,  is  estimated  at

LAND ACQUISITION AND RESETTLEMENT: 
SECTOR LENDING ARRANGEMENTS AND SUBPROJECT RESETTLEMENT PLANS 

Background 

 
A. 
 
1. 
In  accordance  with  the  involuntary  resettlement  policy  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB),1 the handling of resettlement and land acquisition for sector loans such as the proposed 
Project requires the preparation of (i) a resettlement policy framework and procedural guidelines 
(RPFPG)  applicable  to  all  subprojects,  and  (ii)  a  specific  resettlement  plan  (RP)  for  each 
subproject.  The  preparation  of  RPFPG  and  at  least  one  RP  for  each  core  subproject  is  a 
condition for project appraisal. Additional RPs with detailed design and acceptable to ADB will 
be  prepared  as  a  condition  for  approval  of  ADB  financing  for  the  other  subprojects.  The 
Songliao  Water  Resources  Commission  (SWRC),  in  consultation  with  the  relevant  provincial 
management  offices  (PMOs),  has  prepared  the  RPFPG  and  the  RP  for  the  Qunli  dike 
subproject (a core subproject involving substantial resettlement and land acquisition).2 This work 
is complemented by an initial social assessment (ISA) providing preliminary impacts data for the 
other core and noncore subprojects. This Appendix summarizes the RPFPG and the RP for the 
Qunli dike subproject, and reviews the impact data available for the other subprojects. The RP 
for Qunli dike subproject is given in Supplementary Appendix A and the RPFPG for the Project 
is given in Supplementary Appendix B. 
 
B. 
 

Resettlement Policy Framework and Procedural Guidelines 

1. 

Policy Framework 

 
2. 
The  RPFPG  reflects  both  Chinese  legal  requirements  and  ADB’s  policy.  The  main 
principles  follow:  (i)  minimizing  negative  impacts  as  much  as  possible;  (ii)  carrying  out 
resettlement and compensation so as to improve or at least restore the preproject income and 
living  standards  of  affected  persons  (APs);  (iii)  fully  informing  and  consulting  the  APs  on 
compensation  options  and  resettlement  planning;  (iv)  providing  asset  compensation  at 
replacement  rates;  and  (v)  compensating  in  full  for  lost  assets,  replacement  dwellings  and 
resettlement allowances prior to ground leveling and demolition. ADB approval of a subproject 
involving resettlement will be subject to ADB's approval of the subproject RP. 
 
3. 
The  RPFPG  stipulates  eligibility  and  entitlements  for  land,  houses,  income  losses,  and 
rehabilitation subsidies in accordance with the 1998 Land Administration Law, Municipal Urban 
Demolition  Regulations,  and  ADB’s  policy.  As  Chinese  laws  and  regulations  allow  for  various 
alternatives  in  compensation  eligibility,  methodology,  and  rates,  each  subproject  RP  will  give 
specific  provisions  within  the  allowable  options  and  ranges  based  on  the  land  productivity 
features of each subproject site and intensive consultation with local communities. The general 
options and compensation ranges are described below. 

(i)  Permanent land losses will be replaced through land reallocation within village domains 
and through the payment of (a) a land compensation fee, and (b) a resettlement subsidy. 
Land compensation will range between 6 and 10 times of the average annual output value 
(AAOV) and the resettlement subsidy will range between 4 and 6 times the AAOV. These 
funds may be wholly paid to the affected villages, which will reinvest them for productive 

                                                 
1  Asian Development Bank. 1998. Handbook on Resettlement: A Guide to Good Practice. Manila. 
2  A resettlement plan has also been completed for Du’erbenxin dike, a core subproject. 

 

 

 

 

 53 

Appendix 7, page 2 

improvements benefiting the affected communities; in special situations they may be given 
to the APs or shared by the village and the APs. In the latter case, villages will receive the 
land compensation and the APs the resettlement subsidy. If farmland reallocation lowers 
the minimum village per capita land ratio beyond the allowable ratio, sufficient APs will be 
reclassified and provided with jobs. 

 
(ii)  Temporary  land  losses  will  be  paid  for  in  cash  to  the  APs  at  the  rate  of  2  times  the 

AAOV. 

 
(iii)  Residential  land  will  be  compensated  either  through  "land  for  land"  arrangements  in 
village  domains  or,  in  the  case  of  subprojects  in  urban  areas,    by  adding  to  the 
compensation for houses and buildings the substitution value of the residential land lost. 

 
(iv)  House/buildings  losses  will  be  paid  to  the  APs  in  cash  at  replacement  cost  free  of 
demolition expenses and salvaged materials. In case residential land is provided through 
"land  for  land"  arrangements,  the  APs  will  rebuild  the  houses.  If  residential  land  is 
compensated in cash, the APs will use the compensation to purchase apartments. 

 
(v)  Crops losses will be paid to the APs in cash at the rate of a single AAOV. 
 
(vi)  Various  relocation  subsidies  covering  transport,  work  losses,  transfer  costs,  medical 

expenses, temporary housing, and a resettlement bonus will be paid to the APs. 

 
(vii)  Business  losses  allowance  based  on  tax  declarations  will  be  paid  to  each  AP  so 

affected for each month of interruption of business activities. 

2. 

Resettlement Procedural Guidelines 

 
 
 
The RPFPG establishes the following procedures for the preparation of subproject RPs: 
4. 
(i) after subproject identification and completion of preliminary design, the relevant PMO carries 
out an ISA to determine preliminary impact data and to identify the socioeconomic features of 
the  APs;  (ii)  if  through  this  process  subproject  impacts  are  identified  as  “significant,”3  the 
provincial/regional  PMO  will  prepare  a  full  RP;  (iii)  if  impacts  are  less  than  “significant,”  the  
PMO will prepare a short RP.4 

 
3. 

Institutional Responsibilities 

 
 
5. 
Because  this  is  a  sector  loan  project,  the  Ministry  of  Water  Resources  through  SWRC 
has overall coordination responsibility for the three provincial/regional PMOs and the proposed 
structural subprojects. In turn, each PMO has full responsibility for coordinating the subproject 
offices with respect to project planning, implementation, and financing. Subproject offices will be 
tasked with preparing and implementing specific RPs and will share responsibilities with cities, 
townships,  counties,  and  local  land  management  and  resettlement  offices  for  resettlement 
activities  such  as  asset  valuation;  consultation;  delivery  of  entitlements;  and  issuance  of  land 
acquisition,  demolition,  and  building  permits.  Field  tasks  such  as  paying  compensation, 
selecting replacement land, and providing livelihood support will rest with township and village 
officers. 

                                                 
3  Significant  impacts  are  defined  as  follows:  (i)  200  or  more  APs,  (ii)  100  or  more  APs  belonging  to  national 

minorities or vulnerable groups. 

4  For full and short RP formats, see ADB’s Handbook on Resettlement: A Guide to Good Practice.

4. 

5. 

6. 

Grievance Procedures 

Monitoring and Evaluation 

Disclosure and Public Consultation  

 
 
 
6. 
RP preparation will entail intense public consultation carried out through questionnaires 
and  community  meetings  involving  implementing  agencies,  local  governments,  and  APs.  An 
information booklet summarizing RPFPG provisions will be sent to all APs while the RPFPG and 
the  RP  in  the  Chinese  language  will  be  available  in  each  village.  The  same  documents  in 
English will be available at ADB Headquarters and the Resident Mission. 
 
 
 
7. 
Complaints and grievance procedures will be established in the RPs. Grievances will be 
lodged  first  with  the  village  committee.  If  no  settlement  is  reached  within  two  weeks,  the 
complainant will have one month to raise the case with the county land administration bureau or 
building demolition office. If the case is still unresolved within two weeks, it can be sent to the 
subproject office. Final appeal will be made in the civil courts under Chinese law. 
 
 
 
8. 
As required by ADB, both internal and external monitoring of RP implementation will be 
carried  out.  The  PMOs  will  establish  in  collaboration  with  SWRC  a  monthly  reporting  system 
involving resettlement staff at township and county levels. External monitoring will be assigned 
to  an  independent  monitoring  agency  (IMA).  The  PMOs  will  report  to  ADB  on  land  acquisition 
and resettlement in the quarterly progress reports. External monitoring reports will be submitted 
to ADB twice a year. 
 
 
 
Each RP will establish the unit compensation rates for the items negatively affected by 
9. 
the  subproject  and  will  give  a  detailed  assessment  of  the  cost  of  the  resettlement  and  land 
acquisition  programs.  These  will  include  asset  compensation  inclusive  of  land  compensation, 
resettlement  subsidies,  and  house/improvements  replacement;  income  restoration  assistance; 
relocation  allowances;  management  costs;  monitoring  and  evaluation;  taxes;  and  contingency. 
Cost estimates will be adjusted annually based on the inflation rate of the preceding year. 
 
C. 
 
 
 
10. 
Three core subprojects, one for each province, were selected: Qunli dike in Harbin City, 
Heilongjiang  Province;  Du'erbenxin  rural  flood  control  embankment,  Inner  Mongolia;  and 
Xianghai  reservoir  rehabilitation,  Jilin  Province.  Of  these,  the  Du'erbenxin  rural  flood  control 
embankment requires a short RP, which has been completed. The Qunli dike requires a full RP. 
The  full  Qunli  dike  RP  was  prepared  as  model  for  the  other  subprojects  (Supplementary 
Appendix A) and is summarized in the following paragraphs. 
 
11. 
The Qunli dike subproject entails the construction of 10.3 km and the rehabilitation of 3.3 
km of dikes on the south bank of the Songhua River in Daoli District, Harbin City. In accordance 
with Chinese laws and regulations and the RPFPG, a full RP was prepared based on advanced 
preliminary  design,  a  socioeconomic  survey,  a  household-to-household  impacts  inventory,  and 
intensive AP consultation. As a condition for contract awards, when detailed design is available, 
a detailed measurement survey will be carried out and, if necessary, impacts assessment and

resettlement costs will be updated. 
 
12. 
The  subproject  will  acquire  118.7  hectares  (ha)  of  which  73.83  ha  are  farmland. 
Temporary  land  impacts  will  affect  339  ha.  Buildings  losses  amount  to  52,831square  meters 
(m2) of houses and 2,674 m2 of structures belonging to five public enterprises. The subproject 
will also remove 34,762 m2 of greenhouses, 87 trees, 23 380kV and 35 220kV electricity poles, 
and  35  tombs.  Overall,  the  APs  are  893:  450  persons  (159  households)  will  be  affected  by 
house relocation; 288 persons (181 laborers), by permanent land acquisition; 145 persons (93 
laborers), by temporary land occupation; and 10 persons, by enterprise relocation. 
 
 
 
The  RP  reflects  the  policy  principles  established  by  the  RPFPG  and  fixes  specific 
13. 
eligibility  provisions,  entitlements,  and  compensation  mode  and  rates  for  the  subproject. 
Permanent land losses will be offset through land reallocation within village domains, while land 
compensation and resettlement subsidies in cash will be paid respectively to villages and APs 
or  public  enterprises.  Villages  will  use  these  funds  for  productive  improvements  benefiting  the 
affected  communities.  The  land  compensation  rate  is  6  times  the  AAOV,  while  the  rate  for 
resettlement  subsidies  is  4  times  the  AAOV.  Temporary  land  losses  will  be  compensated 
directly to the APs at a rate equal to a single AAOV. Premises land of farm deposits and barns 
will  be  compensated  in  terms  of  "land  for  land"  arrangements  in  village  estates.  House, 
greenhouse,  and  improvements  losses  will  be  compensated  in  cash  at  replacement  cost__not 
including  demolition  expenses  and  salvaged  materials__to  their  owners,  whether  APs  or  public 
enterprises.  Crops  losses  will  be  compensated  to  the  AP  in  cash  at  the  rate  of  2  times  the 
AAOV.  Finally,  APs  and  public  enterprises  will  receive  various  allowances  to  cover  transport 
(Y600),  income  loss  (Y300),  damages  (Y150),  medical  fees  (Y20),  and  relocation  bonus 
(Y3,000). Enterprise allowances will cover transport (Y20,000) and wage losses (Y10,000). 
 
 
 
14. 
Because  land  redistribution  will  cause  minimal  per  capita  reduction  of  village  farmland 
(5.2 percent), the reinvestment of land compensation funds in productive improvements such as 
the expansion of greenhouses in dryland plots will be sufficient to maintain the living standards 
of villagers. Moreover, the decision to pay resettlement subsidies directly to the APs will almost 
certainly lead to improvement of these villagers’ livelihood.  
 
All relocatees have chosen to receive both house and residential compensation in cash, 
15. 
instead  of  house  compensation  plus  replacement  plots.  With  compounded  house/residential 
land  compensation  set  at  Y1,200-1,100/m2  for  legal  brick/concrete  and  brick/wood  houses, 
respectively,  and  at Y300-200/m2  for  nonregistered  attachments,  the  relocatees  will  be  able  to 
purchase  new  apartments  in  nearby  areas.  As  current  apartment  prices  range  from  Y900  to 
Y1,700/m2 compensation rates allow for the purchase of apartments larger than the average in 
the project areas and of much better quality than the demolished houses. The viability of farms 
has  been  maintained  by  providing  compensation  for  farm  deposits  and  barns  in  cash  at 
replacement cost for buildings, and "land for land" arrangements for land premises.  
 
16. 
Affected vulnerable households with per capita income below $1/day equivalent, headed 
by  widows  or  divorced  women,  or  composed  of  elderly  APs,  will  receive  special  livelihood 
restoration.  Those  losing  houses  will  be  assisted  in  purchasing  or  constructing  replacement 
housing, and will receive welfare provisions during and after implementation of the resettlement 
programs. Census data show no vulnerable households among the APs.

Institutional Arrangements 

 
 
 
17. 
The subproject PMO will be responsible for RP implementation under the supervision of 
the EA and the office of the Harbin City vice-mayor. Within the PMO, a resettlement unit will be 
responsible for resettlement planning, implementation, and timely delivery of entitlements. City 
and  district  land  administration  bureaus,  urban  demolition  offices,  and  township  and  village 
governments will play important roles in implementing various tasks on the ground. 
 

5. 

Public Consultation, Disclosure, and Grievance Redress 

 
18. 
RP  preparation  and  compensation  methodology  and  rates  setting  were  based  on 
intensive  consultation  carried  out  through  surveys  and  community  meetings  involving  PMO, 
village  officials,  and  APs.  During  RP  implementation  further  consultation  will  be  carried  out  to 
define the details of day-to-day resettlement activities.  
 
An information booklet summarizing the RP will be sent to all APs. The RP in Chinese 
19. 
will  be  made  available  to  the  public  at  the  ADB  Resident  Mission  and  PMO/affected  villages 
offices. The RP in English will be available at ADB's Resident Mission and headquarters.  
 
In  grievance  cases,  APs  will  submit  a  verbal  or  written  complaint  first  to  the  village  or 
20. 
township resettlement office. If the grievance is not settled within two weeks, it may be elevated, 
within  one  month,  to  the  district  resettlement  office.  If  the  case  is  still  unresolved  within  two 
weeks, it can be raised with the subproject PMO. Final appeal will be made in the civil courts. 
 
 
 
21. 
The  PMO  will  monitor  RP  implementation  monthly.  The  IMA  will  carry  out  external 
monitoring  every  six  months.  The  PMO  will  report  quarterly  to  ADB  on  the  progress  of  land 
acquisition, resettlement, and compensation/rehabilitation tasks, while IMA reports will be sent 
to ADB every six months. The IMA will evaluate the performance of the rehabilitation program at 
the end of the resettlement program and a year after.

CONSULTING SERVICES, TRAINING, AND STUDY TOURS 

 
1. 
Developing capacity within the Songliao Water Resources Commission (SWRC) and the 
three provincial project management offices (PMOs) to provide for integrated flood management 
in  the  Songhua  River  basin  is  necessary.  A  combination  of  consulting  services,  training,  and 
study tours has been designed to build this capacity and to implement the Project. An overview 
is in Table A10. Supplementary Appendix C provides details of phasing and terms of reference 
for consultants, and expands on the summary information given here. 
 

1. 

Consulting Services 

 

a. 

Flood Management System (FMS)1 

 
2. 
Consulting  services  will  be  provided  through  an  international  consulting  firm  in 
accordance with the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) Guidelines on the Use of Consultants, 
and  other  arrangements  acceptable  to  ADB  for  selecting  and  engaging  domestic  consultants. 
The  consultant  services  required  under  the  Project  total  688  person-months:  80  international 
and  608  domestic.  The  international  consultants  will  be  recruited  through  an  international 
consulting  firm  selected  and  engaged  using  ADB’s  quality-and-cost-based  selection  (QCBS) 
method. 
 
 
 
3. 
The  FMS  will  be  combined  with  an  efficient  decision  support  system  (DSS).  The 
requirements  will  be  (i)  a  comprehensive  and  integrated  water  information  system,  based  on 
geographic  information  system  (GIS)  techniques;  (ii)  a  basinwide,  state-of-the-art  hydraulic 
model (the core model); (iii) a modern flood forecasting system (FFS); and (iv) an efficient DSS 
based  on  the  three  preceding  components.  The  DSS  can  be  considered  as  the  complete  tool 
(including  GIS,  core  model,  and  the  FFS)  in  preparing  decisions  and  assisting  the  authorities 
during emergencies as well as in a predictive way for flood management strategies. The FMS 
will require 484 person-months (51 international and 433 domestic) of consulting services, made 
up of the following skills and tasks, including training (person-months are in parentheses). 
 
4. 
GIS Specialists (10 international, 110 domestic). Based at SWRC-PMO in Changchun, 
the international specialist will take a lead role in developing GIS capability within SWRC. The 
task  will  comprise  developing  the  logical  and  physical  design  of  GIS  for  the  Songhua  River 
basin; supervising the collection of geographic data, map layers, and other data and building of 
the geodatabase; developing the main system menu and applications; developing the interfaces 
with  the  mathematical  models  in  close  collaboration  with  the  mathematical  model  and  flood 
forecasting  system  specialists;  developing  the  interfaces  with  DSS  in  close  collaboration  with 
the  relevant  specialists  working  on  DSS;  preparing  the  test  phases  of  the  system  along  the 
Project; and giving on-the-job training to SWRC staff.  
 
5. 
Mathematical  Flood  Modeling  Specialists  (20  international,  186  domestic).  The 
international consultant will provide leadership for the team in this area, taking into account the 
relevant hydrologic and hydraulic conditions of the project area. The major tasks of the team are 
to (i) schematize the river and its major tributaries using available data/information initially, and 
set  up  a  more  detailed  scheme  by  adding  information  collected  during  the  additional  surveys 
and the GIS component; set up flood modeling in major cities, and select pilot cases/studies for 
the most relevant/urgent cities; coordinate the flood management activities with GIS, FFS, and 
DSS activities; (ii) together with the GIS and FFS experts, test and calibrate correct interfacing

between  the  model  components;  and  (iii)  study  flood  routing  under  various  scenarios  for 
provinces, cities, and selected counties to define project construction priorities and sequencing, 
efficiency of individual projects and combination of structural and nonstructural measures. The 
team will give on-the-job training on integrated river basin management, river basin plans, policy 
analysis, and flood management studies to staff and senior Government officials in SRWC, and 
relevant PMOs. 
 
6.

(hydrology/meteorology  and  flood  routing)  will  provide  the  leadership  for  the  team  involved  in 
the following tasks: study existing flood forecasting infrastructure and methodology in the basin, 
as  well  as  the  relevant  national  guidelines;  examine  existing  proposals  for  the  extension  of 
workstations  and  hydrological  stations  under  the  Project;  study  existing  meteorological 
conditions and methodology of weather forecasting; set up and support an appropriate rainfall-
runoff  model,  ensure  adequate  connection  with  the  mathematical  flood  model  and  interfacing, 
and assist in calibrating and operating the model; assist in designing and setting up a modern 
and  sound  system  for  flood  forecasting;  assist  SWRC  as  well  as  the  relevant  authorities  at 
provincial  and  regional  levels  in  integrating  the  mathematical  flood  model  in  the  FFS;  and 
ensure  appropriate  interfacing  between  FFS,  GIS,  and  the  core  model,  making  use  of  the 
additional GIS and survey activities under the Project- related training.

14. 
A training and study tour assessment report will be prepared early in implementation. A 
coordinator  for  the  logistical  aspects  will  be  assigned,  while  each  expert  in  the  various  project 
components will give assistance and inputs for this assessment in each field of expertise. About 
2  to  3  person-months  will  be  needed  for  this.  Training  will  be  provided  for  200-250  staff  in 
SWRC, the provinces and autonomous region, and selected local government officials involved 
in implementing resettlement, environmental aspects, and economic evaluation of the candidate 
subprojects.  National  institutions  with  specific  expertise  in  these  areas  will  be  selected  and 
engaged,  in  accordance  with  selection  criteria  and  procedures  acceptable  to  ADB,  to  provide 
targeted training inputs, in consultation with the international consultants. The implementation of 
the  nonstructural  measures  for  flood  management  involves  research  and  development  in  the 
methodology and adoption of new technologies tested elsewhere. Essential to the activities are 
well-trained  groups  of  staff  at  SWRC.  A  combination  of  on-the-job  training  and  specialized 
training  courses  conducted  in  the  country,  and  possibly  outside,  will  be  used.  Supplementary 
Appendix C contains details, including the likely providers of domestic and international training. 
 
15. 
FMS  Component.  Specialized  training  will  comprise  (i)  short-  and  long-term  domestic 
training on selected subjects, by specialized institutes and/or universities, and existing courses;

courses;  (iii)  overseas  specific  training  on  flood  modeling  and  flood  management  at  a

ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL EVALUATION 
 

Introduction 

A. 
 
1. 
The Project will establish the capacity to manage floods in the Songhua River basin and 
upgrade the existing integrated flood protection system, which (i) shields cities, major assets, and 
industries,  and  (ii)  supports  the  sustained  livelihoods  of  about  62  million  people  living  in  the 
floodplain  areas.  Each  subproject  to  be  implemented  as  part  of  the  Project  will  contribute  to 
overall flood control in the Songhua River basin as well as provide protection to locally inundated 
areas. Major economic assets to be protected include the cities of Harbin, Changchun, Jilin, and 
Qiqihar, and the oil field in Daqin. With improved protection, these assets will play an important 
role in the future development of the project area and in the reduction of poverty. However, since 
the  overall  benefits  to  the  entire  floodplain  area  from  improved  management  and  protection 
cannot  be  allocated  between  different  subprojects,  they  have  been  excluded  from  the  current 
analysis.  The  benefits  included  in  each  analysis  in  this  appendix  were  limited  to  direct  and 
quantifiable benefits from local flood protection and, in the case of the core reservoir subproject, 
direct benefits from flood protection and incremental economic activities attributable to improved 
reservoir storage. 
 
2. 
Economic  costs  and  benefits  were  assessed  to  evaluate  the  economic  returns  on  the 
investments  made  in  the  three  core  subprojects.  The  three  are  typical  of  the  26  subprojects 
included in the Project. The analysis was conducted for an asset life span of 40 years, including 
the  construction  period,  which  is  conservative  for  the  types  of  structures  built.  The  costs  and 
benefits were expressed in constant 2001 prices, and valued using the domestic price numeraire 
method.  Financial  costs  of  traded  goods,  net  of  all  taxes  and  duties,  were  adjusted  to  their 
respective economic values using a shadow exchange rate factor (SERF) of 1.07.1 The shadow 
wage  rate  for  unskilled  labor  was  estimated  at  0.9  of  the  prevailing  wage  rate.  All  other  local 
currency  costs  were  assumed  to  equal  their  economic  costs  after  taxes  and  duties  were 
deducted. Financial benefits for the dike subprojects were estimated on the basis of annualization 
of  the  reduction  of  expected  flood  damage,  in  particular  with  respect  to  damage  to  public  and 
private infrastructure (including housing), reduced losses of industrial output and reduced losses 
of agricultural production. For the Xianghai reservoir core subproject, the financial benefits from 
reduced  flood  damage  represent  about  60  percent  of  the  overall  benefits,  the  remainder  being 
derived  from  improvements  to  the  wetlands,  increased  production  from  the  reservoir,  and 
increased agricultural production downstream. 
 
3. 
The economic costs and benefits of the capacity-building activities for the Songliao Water 
Resources Commission (SWRC) and the provincial/regional project management offices (PMOs) 
were  not  analyzed  since  the  economic  value  of  institutional  strengthening  cannot  be  reliably 
estimated. 
 
B. 
 
Since  the  local  authorities,  who  own  the  structures,2  do  not  generate  revenue  from  their 
4. 
flood protection services and do not operate them as financially independent entities, the financial 
internal  rates  of  return  of  the  subproject  investments  are  not  a  relevant  indicator  of  subproject 
sustainability  and  were  therefore  not  calculated.  However,  financial  costs  and  benefits  provided 
the  basis  for  the  subsequent  estimation  of  economic  costs  and  benefits.  Financial  evaluation

August 2001, a project in the same sector.

Economic Costs 

Economic Benefits 

focused  on  the  capacity  of  the  authorities  to  raise  sufficient  revenue  to  sustain  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M) of the facilities and the need for insurance to compensate for losses due to 
floods (paras. 18-19). 
 
C. 
 
5. 
The  subproject  costs  (i)  include  the  costs  of  land  acquired,  voluntary  and  involuntary 
resettlement, surveys and design, construction, construction supervision, environment mitigation 
measures, and subproject management; but (ii) exclude all costs incurred to date for constructing 
and  rehabilitating  flood  control  dikes  and  reservoirs.  The  costs  of  land  acquisition  for  dikes  and 
temporary  construction  sites  as  well  as  for  resettlement  were  based  on  local  compensation 
standards. The costs of buildings to be dismantled due to subproject construction were based on 
their  replacement  or  reconstruction  costs.  These  costs  are  set  out  in  the  resettlement  plans  for 
the  Qunli  dike  and  Du’erbenxin  dike  subprojects  and  are  estimated  as  Y83.0  million  and  Y4.7 
million, respectively. For Xianghai reservoir, no resettlement is required, but Y133,000 has been 
allocated for recovery and regreening of the construction site, and compensation for water losses 
and erosion. 
 
D. 
 
6. 
Economic benefits for the three core subprojects were based on flood damage avoidance 
due  to  the  subproject  investments.  Potential  damage  included  losses  in  fixed  assets  (crops, 
agriculture land, homes, public infrastructure, and industrial equipment and facilities); temporary 
disruptions  of  agricultural  and  industrial  production;  costs  of  emergency  evacuation;  repair  of 
flood control structures; and stunted investment and economic growth due to the prevailing flood 
risk.  Only  direct  and  quantifiable  benefits  attributable  to  flood  protection  in  the  subproject  area 
were  included  in  estimating  benefits.  Thus,  neither  the  broader  downstream  benefits  of  flood 
protection  due  to  retention  of  floodwaters  in  rehabilitated  reservoirs  nor  the  downstream  costs 
due  to  marginal  increases  in  the  risk  of  downstream  flooding  following  dike  strengthening  were 
included.3  For  Qunli  dike,  where  no  information  was  available  on  either  the  costs  or  benefits  of 
potential  residential  and  industrial  developments  in  the  area,  benefits  were  limited  to  those 
directly related to the existing assets and the expected economic growth resulting from improved 
protection of the area.  
 
7. 
At Qunli dike, no account was taken of either the likely increase in value of the protected 
land due to the planned development of the area as a residential, commercial, and service suburb 
of Harbin City, or the increased economic benefits resulting from investments in residential and 
commercial assets following improved flood protection. Harbin Development Office has indicated 
that the value of unimproved land is expected to increase from Y170/square meter (m2) currently 
to  Y550/m2  at  dike  completion.  Although  the  new  development  may  be  more  valuable,  its 
vulnerability to flood damage__and hence the benefits of the dike__depends on the planning and 
design  of  development,  information  that  is  currently  unavailable.    Given  that  the  land  will  be 
developed for commercial and residential use, a complete economic analysis of the dike would, 
for  example,  compare  the  cost  of  the  dike  to  the  cost  of  alternative  measures  of  managing  the 
flood  risk.  The  analysis  presented  here  provides  the  best  available  estimate  of  the  net  benefits 
due to the dike. 

                                                           
3  Rehabilitation of the Xianghai reservoir will allow storage of a greater volume of water in the reservoir during flood 
events, which will result in a marginal reduction in flooding over the entire floodplain. For Qunli dike core subproject, 
where 24.3 square kilometers (km2) of land will be protected from floods with a return period of up to 1-in-50 years, 
the proposed dike will result in a marginal increase in the risk of floods downstream of Harbin City. However, in the 
absence  of  the  mathematical  model  that  will  be  developed  under  the  Project,  it  is  not  possible  to  quantify  these 
marginal impacts. 

  

67 

Appendix 11, page 3 

8. 
Financial  valuation  of  damages  was  based  on  the  values  of  crop  and  industrial  outputs, 
public  infrastructure,  and  industrial  assets  as  recorded  in  the  official  county,  township,  and 
subdistrict statistics.4 For inundated areas, a conservative estimate assumed that a one-season 
crop  was  lost,  which__because  of  the  predominant  types  of  crops  grown__is  equivalent  to  50 
percent  of  annual  crops  in  Qunli  and  100  percent  in  Du’erbenxin.  Potential  losses  of  farm 
implements and household items were not calculated due to lack of data. Likewise, the costs of 
necessary cleanup and silt removal from urban areas and agricultural lands after the floods were 
not  included.  Financial  values  were  converted  to  economic  values  using  conversion  factors  for 
the  civil  works,  materials,  equipment,  and  labor  shares  of  each  type  of  damage.5  The  design 
institutes  and  the  PMOs  provided  subjective  estimates  of  inundation  data  and  asset  loss  rates. 
These were combined with the data on current economic activity in the protected area to estimate 
total  economic  losses  for  varying  levels  of  flood  severity  in  the  with-  and  without-project 
scenarios.  Average  annual  damages  were  then  computed  by  estimating  the  area  under  the 
damage-frequency  curve  (flood  frequency  plotted  against  associated  damages).  Table  A11.1 
presents  the  total  economic  losses  and  annualized  damages  for  the  with-  and  without-project 
scenarios  for  the  three  core  subprojects,  as  well  as  the  incremental  annualized  damage 
avoidance estimated at Y57.4 million for Qunli dike, Y5.5 million for Xianghai reservoir, and Y5.0 
million for Du’erbenxin dike.

9. 
The importance of Xianghai reservoir goes beyond flood protection: it also provides water 
to  the  Xianghai  National  Nature  Reserve,  an  internationally  important  wetland  and  wildlife 
reserve.  The  increased  and  more  assured  supply  of  water  from  the  rehabilitated  reservoir  will 
reduce  the  frequency  of  drought  in  the  area  and  improve  the  environment  for  wildlife.  The 
summary  initial  environmental  examination  gives  a  description  of  the  wildlife  species  and

were collected from the provincial/regional project management office concerned.

68 

Appendix 11, page 4 

biodiversity  in  the  area  served  by  Xianghai  reservoir:  over  300  kinds  of  vertebrate  wildlife, 
including 286 kinds of birds, of which 17 belong to nationally and globally protected birds.6 While 
no attempt was made to quantify the direct environmental benefits, those derived from increased 
reed  production  in  the  nature  reserve  and  increased  tourism  were  quantified  and  included. 
Additional  benefits  arising  from  increased  fisheries  in  the  reservoir  and  increased  water 
availability  to  supplement  two  downstream  reservoirs  (Xinglong  and  Shengli)  used  for  irrigated 
agriculture were also identified and quantified. 
 
10. 
Other financial benefits of rehabilitating the reservoir were estimated based on information 
provided by Jilin PMO. Within the wetlands, reeds are grown on about 15,000 ha (227,000 mu) or 
14.4  percent  of  the  105,000  ha  total  area  of  the  reserve,  and  current  annual  production  is 
estimated  at  about  20,000  tons  (t).7  The  reported  gross  value  is  Y184/t,  of  which  net  value 
represents  about  65  percent.  Improved  reliability  of  the  water  supply  will  increase  the  output  of 
reeds  and  reduce  production  variability  within  the  existing  area.  Average  yield  is  expected  to 
increase  by  about  100  percent  over  a  five-year  development  period,  which  is  not  expected  to 
have an adverse impact on price. Incremental annual production was estimated at Y3.6 million. 
 
11. 
The number of tourists visiting the Xianghai Reserve had increased from about 25,000 in 
1996  to  about  44,000  in  2001,  with  foreign  tourists  accounting  for  about  5  percent  of  the  total. 
Average expenditure was estimated at about Y200/person.8 This estimate included tourists from 
Jilin Province and represented less than 1 percent of tourists visiting the province. Local tourism 
in  both  Jilin  Province  and  Xianghai  Reserve  is  expected  to  continue  to  expand  as  China 
develops. But without the subproject, the capacity of the Xianghai wetlands to cater to increased 
tourism demand will remain limited due to frequent droughts. Thus it was assumed that without 
the  Project,  the  number  of  tourists  would  continue  to  increase  at  the  historical  rate  up  to  a 
maximum of 80,000/year by the year 2016 and would then remain constant. With the Project, the 
increase was assumed to continue at the historic rate up to a maximum of 100,000/year by the 
year 2023. Per capita expenditure was assumed to remain constant at Y200/person both with and 
without  the  Project.  The  incremental  annual  value  of  tourism  is  estimated  at  Y4.0  million  by  full 
project development. 
 
12. 
The increased capacity of the rehabilitated reservoir for water storage is expected to result 
in  benefits  to  both  the  fish  catch  and  irrigated  agriculture.  Annual  fish  catch  is  expected  to 
increase  from  250  t  to  400  t  over  a  six-year  period,  while  the  value  of  the  fish  is  expected  to 
remain constant at about Y10/kilogram (kg). Based on an estimated fish net value of 55 percent 
of  its  gross  value,9  incremental  production  is  estimated  at  Y0.8  million.  Irrigation  benefits  are 
estimated based on a potential incremental area of 2,670 ha (40,000 mu) irrigated from the two 
downstream  reservoirs  in  a  good  year,  and  an  average  annual  area  of  about  50  percent  of 
potential. Currently 2,330 ha (35,000 mu) of the land is planted to maize, which has a yield of 6 
t/ha and a financial price of Y0.92/kg, and the remainder is unused. Rice is expected to similarly 
yield 6.0 t/ha with a financial price of Y1.28/kg. Full adoption of the cropping pattern is expected 
to take five years following completion of rehabilitation. The incremental financial benefits of rice 
production were estimated at Y1.4 million by full development.

Based on ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects, reeds, which are used 
for  specialized  paper  making,  and  tourism,  which  comprises  predominantly  local  tourists,  were 
assumed to be nontraded goods for which the appropriate economic conversion factor using the 
domestic  price  level  numeraire  is  1.0.  Hence  the  economic  values  for  these  outputs  were  the

distribution. Since the People’s Republic of China only periodically imports and exports, average 
parity  prices__Y1.19/kg  for  rice  and  Y0.90  for  maize__are  considered  to  be  most  appropriate  for 
the analysis. With-Project economic benefits are thus estimated at Y32.9 million, compared with 
Y24.6  million  with  no  Project,  giving  an  incremental  annual  value  of  almost  Y8.3  million  (Table

14.  With the Project, economic growth associated with improved flood protection, and hence 
annualized damage avoidance, was assumed to increase at 2-3 percent per annum for the Qunli 
dike and Xianghai reservoir subprojects where significant development has already occurred, and 
3-5 percent for the Du’erbenxin dike subproject, which is currently at a low level of development 
and has considerable investment and economic growth potential.  
 
E. 
 
The economic internal rates of return (EIRRs) were estimated as 26.7 for Qunli dike, 13.6 
15. 
for  Xianghai  reservoir,  and  13.4  percent  for  Du’erbenxin  dike.  The  wide  range  between  the 
Du’erbenxin  dike  and  Qunli  dike  subprojects  reflects  the  diversity  of  benefits  from  investing  in 
flood protection in a completely rural area and in one located on the urban fringe of a large city. 
The estimated EIRR for the Xianghai reservoir subproject reflects the benefits of flood protection 
as  well  as  the  gains  to  wildlife  protection  that  result  from  increased  tourism  activity  in  the 
subproject  area,  and  the  benefits  from  increased  water  storage,  which  will  reduce  risk  and 
increase production. Similar EIRRs are expected for the other subprojects to be included in the 
Project. These estimates are robust, given the relatively limited scope of benefits accounted for in 
the economic evaluation. The EIRRs provide conservative estimates of the economic value of the 
Project,  given  that  the  benefits  excluded  avoidance  of  substantial  social  and  longer-term  costs 
that  are  not  easily  quantified,  including  avoidance  of  injuries,  hospitalization,  loss  of  lives, 
mobilization of flood-fighting crews, and large-scale emergency evacuation that will occur during 
major floods. The economic evaluation also excluded losses due to disruption of communication, 
transportation, education, and family life as well as loss of household assets, livestock, and farm 
machinery.

G. 
 
Funds  are  collected  and  allocated  at  the  provincial/regional  level  for  construction  and 
17. 
maintenance of flood control infrastructure through the Water Resources Construction Fund and 
the  Construction  Fund  for  Flood  Control  Infrastructure.  Similar  funds  have  been  established  in 
Harbin  City  (Heilongjiang)  and  Tongyu  County  (Jilin),  where  annual  fund  collection  amounts  to 
about Y18.7 million and Y0.3 million. These are currently used to finance construction but will be 
reallocated to maintenance on completion of the structures. 
 
18. 
O&M  of  the  dikes,  reservoirs,  and  related  infrastructure  in  the  newly  constructed  and 
rehabilitated  subprojects  will  be  the  responsibility  of  the  relevant  county  or  city.  Annual  O&M 
costs  are  estimated  at  about  3.5  percent  of  construction  costs,  including  in-kind  community 
contributions. O&M costs of infrastructure rehabilitated under the Project are expected to be lower 
than  the  current  O&M  cost  of  these  structures,  at  least  in  the  medium  term.  Nonetheless,  the 
implementing  agencies  do  not  foresee  a  significant  reduction  in  O&M  commitment  after  the 
Project. 
 
19. 
The  flood  insurance  market  remains  undeveloped  and,  even  with  progress  following 
entry into the World Trade Organization, most households, particularly the poor, will continue 
to rely in the foreseeable future on ad hoc payments from national and local governments to 
compensate for flood losses. The level of compensation varies between provinces and regions 
and  even  between  towns  and  counties  within  provinces.  Compensation  for  Du’erbenxin 
township  following  the  1998  flood  amounted  to  about  Y1.55  million  from  the  central 
Government  for  house  construction,  Y0.3  million  from  the  national  Agricultural  Land 
Development Fund for farmland, and Y0.1 million from the township for roads. The extent of 
compensation  was  equivalent  to  about  Y5,000  per  household  for  the  loss  of  a  house.10  No 
information is available for Heilongjiang or Jilin provinces.

SOCIAL AND POVERTY IMPACT ASSESSMENT 

Government Policies on Poverty Reduction 

Socioeconomic Characteristics of the Songhua River Basin 

 
A. 
 
1. 
Since  1994,  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  has  been  implementing  a  poverty 
reduction  program  in  counties  officially  classified  as  poor  by  national  or  provincial  standards  in 
remote  mountains,  desert  and  loess  plateau  regions,  reservoir  catchments,  areas  with  endemic 
local  disasters  and  former  revolutionary  bases.1 Poor  transport,  environmental  degradation,  slow 
economic  growth,  lack  of  drinking  water,  and  extremely  harsh  conditions  for  production  and 
livelihood  characterize  those  locations.  For  the  northeastern  provinces  (including  the  flood-prone 
area to benefit from the Project), poverty reduction efforts involve (i) identifying locally appropriate 
mechanisms  to  address  the  remaining  clusters  of  poverty,  (ii)  mobilizing  national  support  and 
human  and  financial  resources  in  the  relatively  well-off  areas  to  assist  poverty  reduction  efforts, 
and (iii) strengthening water management infrastructure along the lower reaches of the major rivers 
to prevent severe floods and major relapses into poverty.  
 
B. 
 
2. 
The  Project  will  finance  a  range  of  flood  management  and  control  subprojects  in  the 
Songhua  River  basin  (population  62.4  million  people).  Of  the  total  130  counties  or  cities  in  the 
basin,  72  are  in  Heilongjiang  Province,  38  in  Jilin  Province,  and  18  in  Inner  Mongolia.  Only  two 
counties belong to Liaoning Province. The total gross domestic product (GDP) for the basin in 2000 
was Y485.4 billion, averaging Y7,778 per person (Table A12.1). 
 
3. 
The area is relatively urbanized, with 43.3 percent of the population living in cities or towns, 
and 35.4 million people in rural areas. About 17.4 million hectares (ha) or 31 percent of the area is 
farmland. On average, each rural person has about 0.5 ha (7.4 mu) of farmland, ranging from 4.8 
mu  per  person  in  Jilin,  to  11.6  mu  per  person  in  Inner  Mongolia,  which  is  much  higher  than  the 
national  average.  A  study  by  the  Songliao  Water  Resources  Commission  (SWRC)  found  that  66 
counties with a population of 32.7 million (52.5 percent) are at high risk of drought and flooding. In 
those counties, about 70 percent of the people live in rural areas. Average per capita rural income 
is about Y2,000, about 8 percent lower than the river basin average; and rural per capita GDP is 
Y5,086, about one third less than the river basin average. The livelihoods and crops of rural people 
are vulnerable to natural disasters such as floods.

6. 
Substantial  progress  has  been  achieved  in  reducing  poverty  in  the  project  provinces.  In 
1994,  Heilongjiang  had  2.3  million  people  below  the  government’s  poverty  line  (total  population 
37 million).4 By 1998, only 460,000 were classified as poor, but due to the 1998 flood the number 
of poor people rose to 1.2 million. In Jilin over a 20-year period to 1998, poverty was reduced from 
30 percent to only 5.5 percent. After 1998, the number of poor increased by 19 percent. In Inner 
Mongolia where half of all counties are national or provincial poverty counties, the poor numbered 
1.1 million after the 1998 flood.

The 1998 flood affected 88 counties or cities and 17.3 million people, accounting for 67.7 
percent of total counties and 27.8 percent of the population in the basin. Damaged and destroyed 
houses totaled 1.4 million. Agricultural losses in the basin were estimated at about Y2.3 billion and 
direct economic losses were over Y4.8 billion, averaging Y770 per person for the whole basin. The 
1998  floods  pulled  down  hundreds  of  thousands  of  people  below  the  poverty  line,  wiping  out 
achievements of over many years (Table A12.4). In Tangyuan County (Heilongjiang), the number 
of  poor  people  increased  700  percent  above  the  preflood  1998  situation.  Keyoushang  County  in 
Inner Mongolia experienced a 100 percent rise in the number of people under the official poverty 
line.

9. 
In addition to high poverty incidence, the two rural core subproject areas have a significant 
ethnic  minority  population:  34  percent  in  Xianghai  and  58  percent  in  Du’erbenxin.6 Both  Xianghai 
and  Nuwenmuren  are  minority  townships  with  the  majority  comprising  Mongols,  an  important 
minority  group.  In  general,  the  minority  groups  often  live  in  remote  hilly  areas  and  derive  their 
incomes largely from rain-fed terrace cultivation, combined with herding. There is also a strong link 
between  poverty  and  minority  status.  For  example,  in  Xianghai  and  Du’erbenxin,  all  minority 
villages are also poverty villages, with per capita incomes lower than the township average. Among 
the four villages in Du’erbenxin, three villages are minority villages with average per capita income 
of  Y800,  while  the  remaining  Han  village  has  an  average  per  capita  income  of  Y1,400.  Lack  of 
skills  and  capital  to  improve  irrigation  conditions  are  cited  as  reasons  for  higher  poverty  in  the 
minority areas. 
 
10. 
In the two rural subproject areas, although per capita farmland area was high (about 10 mu 
or 0.7 ha), most of the area is low quality dryland with low yield. For irrigated land, average annual 
yield could reach 400 kg per mu. For dry land, under good weather, the average annual yield could 
reach 150 kg per mu, or Y150 per mu, with net income being only Y50 per mu. In bad years with 
flooding or drought, little output is expected. In fact, both Xianghai and Du’erbenxin project areas 
have  suffered  serious  droughts  in  the  past  three  years,  following  the  1998  flood.  In  2000,  many 
villagers  in  Du’erbenxin  relied  on  the  Government  for  food  supply.  Interviews  with  village 
individuals indicated that loss caused by the 1998 flood, lack of capital, and lack of knowledge had 
prevented  them  from  improving  irrigation  conditions  and  investing  in  other  non-planting  activities. 
For example, to dig a deep well that could irrigate up to 5-6 ha of farmland requires an investment 
of approximately Y2,800. The 1998 flood__which destroyed two villages and inundated all farmland 
in the area__and continuous droughts since did not give these poor farmers a chance to recover, or 
invest to improve farming conditions. Women, who form a significant percentage of the rural labor 
force, are typically burdened during such difficult events by the need to obtain drinking water, fuel, 
and  food  to  help  maintain  the  health  of  family  members  and  household  livestock,  and  to  protect 
household properties. Children are affected by such serious poverty, since some households could 
not afford to send their children to school. Unlike households in the Qunli-affected area that derive 
only 25 percent of income from agriculture (56 percent of their incomes from nonfarm employment), 
those  from  the  two  rural  subproject  areas  derive  over  80  percent  of  their  income  from  farming, 
particularly  cultivation  of  grain,  which  is  vulnerable  to  floods.  The  proposed  embankment  and 
reservoir rehabilitation projects will not only provide flood protection and improve irrigation to these 
poor farmers, but also offer an opportunity to build savings for other income-generating activities. 
 
C. 
 
11. 
The  Project  will  yield  social  benefits  for  all  residents  of  the  flood-prone  area  through 
reduced  risks  to  personal  safety,  livelihood,  and  assets.  Flood  warning  and  escape  facilities  and 
procedures will be improved in ways that create greater community involvement. This is important 
for  agricultural  producers  who  rely  heavily  on  grain  grown  for  home  consumption,  livestock 
fattening,  and  for  income.  Funds  previously  devoted  to  insurance  or  replacement  of  assets  will 
become available for alternative productive and consumptive uses. Those most likely to benefit are 
riverside residents (typically poorer households) whose flood-related losses have eroded resource 
reserves and restricted investment. These residents total roughly 15.4 million in Heilongjiang, 15.0 
million in Jilin, and 2.3 million in Inner Mongolia. Village interviews strongly suggested that poorer 
households forgo investment in higher income enterprises such as livestock production for fear that 
animals  will  be  lost  to  floods.  Moreover,  frequent  house  reconstruction  drains  their  capacity  to 
accumulate financial resources. The poorer residents will benefit from the security provided by the 

Overview of Social Benefits  

                                                 
6  For the Qunli subproject, the total protected area (30,000 persons) includes two minority villages with 1,400 persons, 

or 4.7 percent. Most are of Korean nationality with the same income and living standard as in the other villages. 

  

75 

Appendix 12, page 5 

Project Employment Impact  

Project  in  flood  mitigation  and  improved  local  government  financial  capacities.  Data  collected  in 
both  Tongyu  County  and  Zalaite  Banner  indicates  low  levels  of  Government  investment  in  local 
social  services  and  provision  of  infrastructure,  particularly  for  drinking  water,  local  clinics,  and 
roads.  Confidence  that  public  infrastructure  investments  will  be  more  secure  will  support  more 
investment in these locations. For Qunli, the improvement of flood protection will encourage urban 
development, during which both local communities and urban residents will significantly benefit.  
 
12. 
Although  creating  the  necessary  environment  for  income  generation,  the  Project  will  not 
focus assistance to the poor. Flood mitigation requires that control structures be placed in the most 
strategic locations to minimize inundation rather than in areas with the largest number of the poor. 
Further, the Project is not intended to support improvement of the income-generation capacities of 
households or to address the key impediments to poverty reduction in each location. The Project 
will,  however,  assist  poor  residents  in  the  following  ways:  (i)  it  will  foster  community  consultation 
and planning in designing subprojects and formulating resettlement plans, which will enhance the 
community’s role in devising appropriate means of income restoration and allocation of funds and 
technical assistance; (ii) adequate compensation to be paid to local villages for land acquisition and 
resettlement following the new Land Administration Law will provide these villages an opportunity 
to  improve  their  farming  conditions;  (iii)  priority  in  employment,  particularly  in  constructing  and 
maintaining the platforms and other related local facilities, will be given to poor households. 
 
D. 
 
13. 
During  implementation,  the  Project  will  generate  incomes  for  the  floodplain  communities, 
including the poor, from labor-intensive construction of dikes and reservoirs. Preliminary estimates 
indicate that approximately 5.3 million person-days of manual employment will be generated over 
the next four years, providing employment for about 45,000 unskilled laborers during that period. 
About  1.1  million  person-days  at  the  three  core  subproject  sites  during  the  next  two  years  will 
provide  20-150  days  of  employment  for  about  8,600  unskilled  laborers.  Based  on  the  estimated 
poverty incidence at the subproject sites and with priority to the poor in jobs at those sites, about 
50  percent  of  employment  estimated  to  be  worth  about  Y460  million  in  wages  will  be  directed  to 
poor households. Jobs will also be available for maintenance, the cost of which is estimated at 1 
percent of the construction cost, or about Y8 million per year. This work is likely to provide about 
10,000 person-days per year. Although project activities are not aimed at income generation, extra 
incomes from construction work will build savings to improve farming conditions, finance income-
generating activities, and reduce the risk of falling back into poverty. 
 
E. 
 
14. 
The three core subprojects were analyzed to assess the distribution of subproject benefits 
to  project  stakeholders:  households,  industry,  and  the  economy.  A  study  also  assessed  how  the 
Project directly benefits the poor. Economic analysis showed benefits to households were derived 
from  employment  opportunities,  and  direct  avoidance  of  flood  damage  to  crops  and  houses  and 
disruption  in  farming  activities.  Industries  will  benefit  through  reduced  risk  of  damage  and  less 
interruption  in  operations,  while  the  public  sector  will  benefit  from  prevented  damage  to  public 
infrastructure and savings of flood evacuation costs for the affected population. During construction, 
laborers  will  accrue  benefits  from  employment  opportunities.  The  public  sector  will  gain  tax 
incomes,  but  will  bear  most  of  the  costs  of  investment.  Table  A12.6  presents  the  results  of  the 
distribution analyses. The poverty impact ratios are 0.18 for the Qunli subproject, 0.94 for Xianghai, 
and 0.80 for Du’erbenxin.
